Indian Residential School,
Spanish,
Ontario,
May 1st, 1933.

To the Secretary of
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,

Re: Septic Tanks for Sewage

Dear Sir,

I beg to apply to the Department for assistance in the construction of septic tanks which I propose to build as soon as possible to give an adequate sewage system for the two schools here.

They are urgently required. The river has been getting steadily lower for the last few years with the result that the schools now run a great risk of getting a serious epidemic in the summer from the exposed sewage which the river does not carry away.

The estimated cost for both schools would be if metal tanks are used about:

Metal Tanks (2) $595.00
Tiling 450.00
Piping 300.00
Transport & setting up 250.00

Total $1595.00
This does not include the cost of the labour which would be nearly all supplied by ourselves.

Mr. Jacoby, who would be in charge of this work, prefers cement. I am writing to the Lyons Fuel & Supply Co. Ltd., at Sault Ste. Marie, Ont., by this post to ascertain the cost. Mr. Jacoby thinks the cost would be less and the results better than with the metal tanks. I shall let you know the estimates as soon as I have them.

Yours very truly,

Paul Meyer
Ottawa, May 3, 1933.

Rev. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 1st instant, with reference to the proposed new septic tanks for the Spanish Residential School.

It is noted that you are securing an estimate of the cost of cement and, as soon as you obtain this, you should advise the Department and a decision will then be made regarding what amount the Department can allow.

In preparing the plans for the septic tanks, do you feel assured that you are building them large enough, not only for present requirements, but also to provide for any increase that may occur in the future?

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. P. Mary, S.J.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ont.

May 1st 1933

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Re Singer Sewing Machines.

Dear Sir,

They to make application to the Department for two Singer sewing machines for use in the tailoring shop in the Boys school here. The ones we have now need replacement as they are so old and used up as to be nearly unserviceable.

Can you please let me have one Singer sewing machine No. 15-88 for general use and another to make caps and mitts?

Yours very truly,

Paul Myers

CANADA
Ottawa, May 5, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 1st instant, requesting that two sewing machines be supplied for use in the boys' school at the Spanish Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will not be in a position to decide whether funds are available to supply these machines until we are definitely aware as to the cost of installing the sewage system. Certain funds were provided in our Estimates, and, if the amount is not all required in installing the sewage system, it may be possible to provide the sewing machines. The matter of supplying the machines will, therefore, have to stand over for the present. I would request that you renew your application for these machines at a later date.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. P. Mery, S.J.,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ont.

Dear Sir,

You will find under separate cover the receipted bills for the septic tanks. The work is now finished with the exception of the connections which has to be made when the new toilets are completed. Each school has now a separate septic tank of a measurement as under:

Total volume..................2' x 3' x 8' x 6'........1308 cu ft
Total volume in gl.............8195 gl
Volume of sludge vat...........15' x 24' x 6' x 8'........1154 cu ft
Volume of sludge vat in gallons........7295 gl
Volume of water vat............3' x 6' x 8'..............144 cu ft

People in the neighborhood are very pleased that the river water which has become so shallow for the last years will not be contaminated any more. To complete the sanitary equipment I have had at the request of the medical inspector of the District, a cement box made for the spring which supplies our drinking water. Besides I have had new toilets built with which the Department will be very pleased for they were warmly commended by the doctors. I have also fitted the dormitories of the boys' school with new supplies. These two last costly items are not included in the septic tanks bills I am sending you. Considering that I have had to build a large cistern for each school with the many necessary works connected therewith, I trust that the total for both of $1570.75 will seem very reasonable to the Department.

I beg to express to the Department my thanks for their kind assistance and sympathy in this matter.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal

Dear Father:

In further reference to the six galvanized steel Tanks supplied to you some time ago, we were very much surprised indeed at your sending us the entire bill of the tinsmith for the work of assembling and soldering the six Tanks.

In the first place you requested a price on these Tanks "to be made in two sections" and we quoted accordingly, but certainly did not include the cost of assembly at Spanish in the price which we quoted.

In your letter of September 14th you made certain complaints as to the very poor condition in which these Tanks were received. We hold a receipt from the Railway Co. for the shipment as being received by them in good order. You should not have taken delivery of the shipment in a damaged condition without having the particulars of any such damage noted on the freight bill. This also applies to the solder and rivets, as sufficient quantity of these materials were included to complete the Tanks.

In our letter of September 18th we covered your objections pointing out that the Tanks did not require the extra rings around top from a standpoint of strength.

The complaint which you made that "the outlet flange connections were not properly soldered" was the only one for which we thought we might be in any way responsible, and in the last paragraph of our letter we stated that we would stand the expense of having these outlet connections made right. This could not have taken more than an ounce or two of solder per flange - say two pounds altogether and we are quite willing to pay for this, also for four or five hours time of a tinsmith to go over these flanges, but we certainly cannot consider paying for assembling the Tanks and putting around the extra supports which you have put on.
ST. PETER CLAVER SCHOOL.

As you would have had to bring in a Tinsmith anyway to assemble your Tanks we do not see why we should pay for even one of his trips let alone both of them.

We note the first item on your bill of expenses is 20 pounds of solder at 42¢ per pound. We buy the best here at 14¢ per pound. Possibly some of the other items are equally overcharged.

We are willing to pay for a couple of pounds of solder and five hours time of a Tinsmith, and even for one of his trips, although we do not think we are in fairness bound to do this, but further than that our responsibility ends.

We are enclosing credit note for this amount which you can attach to our invoice when sending it to the Department at Ottawa. We also return Mr. Brathwaite's bill herewith.

Replying to yours of the 14th we are sorry to note that the steel Water Tanks shipped to you were not satisfactory.

First of all, it was difficult indeed to ship these Tanks in two parts for assembly on the job, as the top section especially was of necessity very flexible, and we were forced to crate them which we did not figure on doing.

We believe the upper and lower sections were all punched from a pattern or template, so they should all be alike. However, the writer is not positive on this point, and the man who made these tanks is out of the city today.

The top rim is made just like all open top Tanks of this class, and we believe would appear much stiffer when rivetted and soldered to the lower section. However, it would not be a bad idea to use the reinforcing rings of your old tanks if they are the same size, but this should not be necessary from a point of strength.

Sufficient solder and rivets were included in the box of fittings to assemble the tanks, but possibly you had not opened the box before writing your letter.

When you asked for the tanks to be shipped in two sections, we certainly concluded that you had a tinsmith available to assemble them or we would not have accepted the order.

We want to be absolutely fair, and if there is anything faulty in the way the outlet flanges are attached we will stand any expense which it costs to have these made right. A local tinsmith could do this work just as well as any man whom we could send, and we would suggest that you secure the

Ottawa, November 3, 1934.

Gentlemen:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Spanish Indian Residential School, in connection with the Lister semi-automatic lighting plant which was recently ordered from you. It appears that the machine is not working satisfactorily, possibly owing to some minor adjustments being required. Due to lack of funds, the Department is not in a position to accept the offer made in your telegram to the Principal of the 29th ultimo, with reference to sending an expert to Spanish.

The Electrician at the school has written the Department as follows:

"The governor does not work; cannot be set. The voltage is too high from the generator and therefore harms the batteries. The automatic switch operates at 125 volts and should close at 117 volts maximum. I suggest a rheostat to regulate voltage."

The Principal further states in his letter that, while your telegram indicates that gasoline should be used, there is an inscription on the machine, stating that crude oil should be used.

The Department knows that your firm is anxious to have this machine operating properly, and I am directing the Principal of the Spanish School to communicate with you. I trust that you will give his correspondence your careful consideration and make any suggestions which you believe advisable. If you agree with the electrician at the school, that a rheostat would overcome the difficulty which he is apparently having, you may forward a suitable rheostat.

I will keep in touch with the School, and, as soon as the necessary adjustments have been made, cheque in payment of your account will go forward.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir,

we have been approached on different occasions by the residents of the Towns of Walford & Spanish. Rebuilding an extension to Spanish, so thinking the extension could be made to pay under conditions I will explain later, we put on a small canvass of the Towns also the farms and dwellings along the supposed extension which met with encouraging results.

Now Sir to make this a paying proposition and enable us to make satisfactory financial arrangements we would have to get contracts and to find the most feasible & lasting contract would be a contract with the College at Spanish.

We opened up negotiations with the Rev. Father Miry, S.J., principal of the college and explained to him the advantages which could be obtained by discarding the present system of Delco Power and tying in with us. We also submitted for his approval data as to costs, etc., comparing both systems financially & otherwise.

Father Miry on our last visit which was within the last two weeks explained they had bought a new Delco Plant, but there is no doubt this plant could be used under similar circumstances where power was not available.

Sir our reason for writing you is, during our conversation with Father Miry he mentioned the fact he would submit our data to the Rep. of the Dept. Of Indian Affairs.

This was the first knowledge we had the Dept might be interested. We took the matter up with Mr. William Darby, of Massey who suggested we should correspond with you.

Sir our correspondence with you is not a means by us of trying to supersede any authority of Rev. Father Miry.

We feel benefits could be derived by all concerned if the extension could at all be made possible.

Thanking you for any effort you might put forward to see if the suggestion could at all be made possible again thanking you we remain

Respect Yours, Lloyd Deagle & Co.

Massey, Ont.

Ottawa, November 22, 1935.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, enclosing letter received by you from Lloyd Eagle & Co., Massey, Ont., with reference to extending their power line to Spanish, Ont., and arranging for the Spanish Indian Residential School to take electricity from them.

The buildings at Spanish used for Indian residential school purposes are owned by the Jesuit Order, and this Department pays a per capita grant for each Indian child placed in the school. We also assist the school from time to time, as funds will permit, in securing the necessary equipment, etc.

At the present time they have their own lighting plant, and the cost of the operation of this is borne by the school from the funds they receive from the per capita grant or other receipts. Any decision regarding the change in their method of securing electric power rests with the school management, and Messrs. Lloyd Eagle & Co. will have to deal with the Principal, who, no doubt, will decide the matter on the basis of cost to the school.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Mindemoya, Ont.

July 26th, 56

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Many thanks for your kind remembrance.

Please find enclosed the measures of the additional structure.

At my last visit at Ottawa, if you remember, I asked Mrs. Sutherland in your presence if she would help me in building better sanitary equipment to replace the poor one which causes so much trouble in the dormitory. Mrs. Sutherland then told me kindly: "You never refused the children we sent you. I shall do it for you."

Now it is a real problem to do it at a minimum expense and in a satisfactory way. I came to the conclusion that I shall do better to accommodate rooms inside than to raise a lower annexed to the building. To give an exact estimate would be difficult. These accommodations will consist in a better toilet room in the dormitory, better heating downstairs with a washing room and shower. Is it too much to ask a grant of $500? If it costs more, I will probably pay the balance from the per capita grant.

All are well at Spanish. I hope that the heat wave does not hit too hard at Ottawa.

Sincerely yours,

Rev. P. Mery S.J.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources;

Dear Sir:

We have extensive plumbing repairs and installations to make and we cannot meet the expense. Therefore, I put the matter before you and ask financial help.

Our present will provide scarcely for current accounts and minor repairs and improvements that must be made. They include paint and cleansers; re-newal of cutlery for boys and staff; 24 new matresses, 36 feather pillows, 12 beds with still more to be ordered; repairs on the foundation of the shoe shop; and an expensive arrangement with local fishermen by which boys are to be supplied with more fish according to a Departmental recommendation sent Nov. 10th 1936, No. 150-44.

These expenses I expect to meet with our present grant, but I cannot hope to pay for essential bath and toilet installations. Showers and toilets in the boys' dormitory have been condemned. They smelled and leaked into a class-room below.

These accommodations must be installed in another part of the house; but that is enough. Toilets are not found on the third floor where eight members of the staff and help sleep.

The infirmary at present has no toilet. In case of an epidemic that circumstance might have serious consequences for the sick and those not sick whose toilets would have to be used as well as give much unnecessary work to the infirmanian.

Contractors ask $1250.00 for installing only the boys' showers and toilets. Please see copies of the contracts enclosed. By doing our own buying, using our own labor and hiring a plumber and one expert for cement work I think we could put in everything we need i.e., infirmary toilets etc for the sum that contractors ask for boys' showers and toilets alone.

We hope to do it for $1231.00. I would ask you therefore to kindly look over the list of catalogue prices enclosed and grant us $1200.00.

Sincerely,

J. Howitt.

That the estimates for the fiscal year 1936-37, Vote Number 169, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, provide an amount of $24,582.00 for new works, repairs and purchase of equipment for the following Church owned Indian Residential Schools:

(a) ONTARIO
   Spanish Roman Catholic Residential School
   Moose Fort Church of England Residential School

(b) SASKATCHEWAN
   Thundershield Roman Catholic Residential School

(c) ALBERTA
   Ermineskin Roman Catholic Residential School
   Grouard Roman Catholic Residential School
   Holy Angels Roman Catholic Residential School
   Joussard Roman Catholic Residential School
   St Albert Roman Catholic Residential School
   Sturgeon Lake Roman Catholic Residential School
   Vermilion Roman Catholic Residential School
   Wabasca Roman Catholic Residential School
   Wabasca Church of England Residential School
   Whitefish Lake Church of England Residential School

(d) NORTHWEST TERRITORIES
   Aklavik Roman Catholic Residential School
   Aklavik Church of England Residential School
   Fort Resolution Roman Catholic Residential School
   Providence Mission Roman Catholic Residential School

(e) BRITISH COLUMBIA
   Ahousaht United Church Residential School
   Cariboo Roman Catholic Residential School
   Christie Roman Catholic Residential School
   Kitamaat United Church Residential School
   Port Simpson United Church Residential School

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Dear Sir:

I am submitting a list of expenses for approval and refund for years 1936-9.

The buildings here have been standing about twenty-years and being of frame are now badly in need of repair. The foundations especially are giving away.

The electric fixtures i.e., wires and piping in the barn are corroded and may cause a fire.

The dock was swept away by high water and the girls were forced to forego several trips in the boat this summer because they could not safely reach the launch which must be kept some distance from the shore.

We have a manual training workshop set up in the school where boys may do a certain amount of carpentry without going to the mill. They have mechanical drawing and make the different according to the specifications of their drawings. However there are very few tools with which to work.

Refund on plumbing repairs will enable our community to pay some debts and personal expenses such as clothing which they could scarcely do last winter when our "salaries" were used to pay for plumbing installations necessary for the children's health.

Yours truly,

J. Howitt.

Thanking you for any trouble you shall go to in this matter.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Spanish Indian Residential School, Spanish, Ont.

The above-mentioned school is church-owned and in the fall of 1937 the Principal advised the Department that certain plumbing repairs and installations were extremely necessary, in fact the showers and toilets in the boys' dormitories had been condemned and required immediate replacement.

At that time the Principal was advised that no funds were available but that provision would be made in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1938-39. In preparing our estimates for the current fiscal year an amount of $1500.00 was provided for repairs and improvements at this school.

The Principal was not aware of our purchasing regulations and following the same practice as he had in the past he immediately proceeded to make the necessary repairs which, as stated above, were very urgently required. A great deal of the labour was performed by the school staff and reports received indicate that a good job was done.

The Principal has now submitted accounts covering the cost of material and the labour of one man amounting in all to $1498.94.

It would be appreciated if the Honourable the Minister would approve of our paying the above account. Funds are available in the current year's appropriation.
as an amount of $1500.00 was included and P.C. 681 of April 23, 1935, gives us the requisite authority to expend the money.

The Principal is being given definite instructions that in future if any funds are provided for repairs and improvements at this school it will be expected that he will strictly comply with the purchasing regulations.

Director,

[Signature]

St. Joseph's Residential School,
Spanish, Ont., May 3, 1939.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Not having heard from you after forwarding to your office my request for material for the cooking class, I wondered several times, lately, if by any chance, my letter was lost in the mail. When Miss Laferriere told me yesterday that hers was lost I felt sure that the same happened to mine, so I am enclosing a duplicate of the order.

In a week or two there will be rhubarb to can, so you see I am getting anxious about the preserving kettles.

When ordering equipment for the Domestic science class, a few years ago, only class work was being done. As each year more girls on leaving school go to work as domestics among white people, we are now giving more time to individual work, so as to fit them better for their positions. To do this properly more utensils are needed and I would be most grateful for the articles, a list of which is enclosed.

A clock is badly needed as the teacher's watch is the only time-piece available which leads her to watch the time of cook and baking instead of the pupils.

As we have large plots of all kinds of berries and rhubarb the girls remaining during the holidays, and later all the industrial girls, canned, made preserves and pickles every day during the season, and so supplied a great amount of the food needed for the winter. To do the work we had to borrow kettles from the kitchen, which was very inconvenient as often they were needed there. Besides we wore out one of their kettles. We would need two large preserving kettles, each holding five gallons to do the work properly. If the Department feels that they cannot afford two one would be better than none but two save a lot of time and fuel as two can be used at the same time.

I have made the selection from Eaton Catalogue, simply to give you an idea of what is needed. The preserving kettles and large strainers are not listed, but they have them in stock, I am sure.

Hoping for a favorable reply from you, and thanking you for the many favours in the past, I remain,

Most respectfully yours,

Elizabeth Lenczak.

Mr. P. Phelan,
Chief Training Division,
Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Dear Sir:

In reply to your query 36-0-5 of October 11 re fire extinguisher re-fills from Fairbanks-Morse Company, I have checked off on the enclosed invoice those items we have received and used.

As regards the "12 only refills for 2½ gal. Fyr Fyter Extinguisher - dozen $8.70", what was sent did not fit our Fyr Fyter Extinguisher and with the company's consent I returned the refills.

The company then sent 12 only anti-freeze refills for standard 2½ gal. Fire Extinguishers, and these did not fit our Fyr Fyter Extinguisher. I wrote the company several times explaining the matter and asking their consent to return the refills, but they never answered.

These 12 anti-refills for Standard 2½ gal. Fire Extinguishers are still here in the condition in which they were received. They are no good to us.

I would suppose that refills that fit Fyr-Fyter Extinguishers are made by the Fyr-Fyter Extinguisher Company.

Yours truly,

J. Rowitt.
Ottawa,
October 20, 1939.

Gentlemen:

On receipt of your letter of the 6th instant I wrote to the Principal of the Spanish residential school in connection with your invoice dated March 25, 1938, amounting to $20.90, also your invoice of May 6, 1938, amounting to $80.40.

In connection with these accounts the Principal writes as follows:

"As regards the "12 only refills for 2½ gal. Pyr Fyter Extinguisher - dozen $5.70", what was sent did not fit our Pyr Fyter Extinguisher and with the company's consent I returned the refills.

"The company then sent 12 only anti-freeze refills for standard 2½ gal. Fire Extinguishers, and these did not fit our Pyr Fyter Extinguisher. I wrote the company several times explaining the matter and asking their consent to return the refills, but they never answered.

"These 12 anti-refills for Standard 2½ gal. Fire Extinguishers are still here in the condition in which they were received. They are no good to us."

In view of the information contained in the Principal's letter an amount of $5.70 is being deducted from your account of $20.90 and a cheque for $15.20 will be forwarded under separate cover.

The Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co., Ltd.,
980 St. Antoine Street,
Montreal, Que.
As the 12 refills for 2½ gal. extinguishers have never been used I am directing the Principal to return them. Under the circumstances it will not be necessary to pay the account of $60.40.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find a list of items required for the next fiscal year. While all the articles are necessary certain ones are essential and if the Department can approve of some only, I would ask that first attention be given to equipment for the new power house and cement for the fire escape or outside stairway and a root house.

This work must be done and the expense, if not borne by the Department, must come from our per capita grant. That together with the cost of a Ruston engine and generator may cripple us.

Due to mishaps at sea delivery of a generator from England has been delayed and the power plant has not yet been installed. The present engine, in need of repairs, has been using an unusual amount of oil and gasoline which runs up our expenses. The Fairbanks-Morse forest fire pump is also important for protection as our present water pressure even with the pump running fails to straighten out the hose.

Mr. Philip Phelan

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

I am proposing the following request for your consideration and assistance, if possible.

Our Lister Diesel Engine which drives the water pump for both schools has been in operation for seven years, running on an average of seven hours daily; may at any time stop running due to long service. A major overhaul would put it in condition suitable for a few more years, but this would mean a long tie up. In the meantime we would be without an engine to supply water to both schools. We propose that a new one be bought to serve our needs during the tie up of the old one and then it could be used as an auxiliary engine, should a break down happen in the future. At present, when a breakdown happens to the old one, we have to work late into the night to make the repairs necessary. So far we have been fortunate enough to always finish on time for the daily consumption of water by the schools, especially the Girls school, where the laundry for boys and girls is washed. Due to the rise in prices of materials, taxes and cut in our grant this year, we can not see our way clear to spend the sum of money re-
quired to purchase the engine we need. So we are making a request to the Dept. to purchase this engine for us.

The engine needed for our purpose is a 3 H.P. Lister Diesel Engine, tank cooled, price $396.00 F.O.B. Toronto. I am enclosing their letter to us on this engine.

We are also in need of a Tractor for our farm work. We are not asking the Dept. to purchase one, but we wish to let you know about our needs, in case you should hear of one being idle, in one or other of the Depts at Ottawa. Fr. Hawkins, told me that he knew of a new tractor, not in use, when he was there, at Heron Bay, Pic River Reserve. This tractor might be available for us and would serve our needs. Of course, we do not want to take this tractor away from Heron Bay, if it can be used up there.

Hoping you will be able to aid us, especially with a Diesel Engine, I remain,

Yours truly

[Signature]

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of June 18th (File 36-0-5) in regard to the appropriation for repairs etc., I have spoken to Miss Laferriere at the Girls' School and she informs me that they could use paint to advantage, also that repairs have been necessary for the roof. For these repairs they engaged a man from Sudbury. Would the Department consider applying part of the appropriation to pay the expenses of these repairs?

As for our school here, there is no end to the repairs it needs and improvements. At present the big dormitory is 87½ feet long by 42½ feet wide. That is big enough for about 65 beds. Instead of 65, we have 107 beds in it, besides their sinks for washing and the corner reamed off for a prefect. It is anything but right. My intention is to take the present infirmary and adjacent room and turn it all into dormitory space. That will give us one dormitory 87½ by 42½ and a second one approximately 90 ft. by 18 ft. We are going to do that this summer if we can.

Secondly, at present, for the 126 boys here, there are four sinks only, with four taps only each, for their washing facilities. We must make a wash-room and after much consideration have our plans made for one. It will be as it were between the two dormitories and will be convenient for both. It will accommodate approximately 68 at a time.

I am enclosing a detailed list of the piping and fittings we will require for the washroom.

These alterations will necessitate some paint also. I prefer the white lead—we can mix our colours. We will also need Boiled Linseed Oil and Turpentine.

The toilets are sadly in need of improvement—it will suffice to say that there are no seats on them—just the bowls.
R.A. Hoey:

The springs and mattresses in the dormitories are, as the little Indian boys would say, "very sad" in general.

It seems to me that the Principal should have a filing cabinet for the records, etc., also a typewriter. The one I am using is a borrowed one. Have you any second hand office equipment (office desk?) on hand?

I understand that Mr. Phelan has visited the school here in the past. He could then verify the statements I have made in this letter.

Trusting we may be able to have some assistance in our needs,

Yours sincerely,

(Rev.) C.A. Primeau, S.J.
Principal.

Encl.

Dear Mr. Hey,

Following up your letter to me of June 18th, 1942, please find enclosed our requisition for further supplies for repairs. Their invoices for the labour mentioned above have not yet been delivered to me but I shall forward them on receipt of the same.

The $700 which would be left for the Boys' School has already been partly used (about $150) to purchase the piping and fittings for the Boys' Wash Room. The balance, I suggest, could be best used in purchasing the Paint etc. requested on the enclosed requisition, and to pay the labour required to make the repairs, or rather some of them, needed (kitchen, etc.), and to purchase what further equipment may be suitable for the kitchens. We needed linoleum for the kitchen -- it is going off the market; that is the laid linoleum, and I had a chance to buy some that was of the pattern we wanted -- so I went ahead and bought it. It cost $126.95 less 10% discount, that is $114.25. Whether you would approve this expenditure or not, I don't know. If not, I shall pay for it myself and have you apply the amount thus left of the $700 for some other needed equipment. I know your position in regard to expenditures over $50.00, so will not be surprised if you prefer that I should not submit the linoleum.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Memorandum:

MR. JACKSON

I am sending forward herewith File No. 36-0-24, Spanish Residential School Audit.

The Spanish School has at this date an enrolment of 250 pupils, for which we allow per capita grant of $160, paid on the basis of 92.24%. This school, the only residential school operated by the Jesuit Order in Canada, consists of two main buildings, both of stone construction - one for girls and the other for boys. In addition to the main buildings, there are the ordinary outdoor buildings - barns, stables, machine sheds, etc.

This school has been operated at a loss over a period of years, despite frequent changes in the principalship. The present Principal, Father Primeau, who was recently appointed, visited the Department twice during the summer months. He intimated at that time that the boys' building, particularly the interior, was in somewhat deplorable condition and was urgently in need of repair. It was his intention also, at that time to undertake a certain amount of reconstruction with the object of enlarging the dormitories. The small dormitories that existed at that time were, in his judgment, very insanitary. In view of the large enrolment and the fact that this is the only Catholic residential school in the eastern section of Ontario and the school to which we send a great many orphans from the province of Quebec, it was decided to allow Father Primeau $1,000 for repairs. The paint referred to by you in our telephone conversation will form part of this allowance. This is, as you have stated, a church-owned school. The expenditures on repairs at this school, however, have been very low over a long period of years. You will note, in the audit statement, that the church authorities have been spending substantial sums on the repair of these buildings from year to year.

I would certainly appreciate it if a definite decision were reached in respect to the policy of the Government on the repair, operation and general upkeep of these church-owned residential schools. I am convinced, after my recent visit to Mount Elgin - a report of which will reach you in due course - that these residential schools should either be kept in a good state of repair or closed. I do not believe, however, that the purchase of paint would mean much one way or the other. If we are to work in close cooperation with these principals, there has got to be a certain amount of "Give and Take" on both sides.

I should like to direct your attention particularly to the salaries paid to the staff at this institution. Were it not for the voluntary services of this staff to accept a nominal salary, the institution could not operate under the present financial arrangement.

It is my understanding that a delegation representing the churches will interview the Minister toward the
end of December. It has occurred to me that the operation, repair and upkeep of our residential schools, particularly the church-owned schools, might be carefully reviewed at that time.

[Signature]

Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Mr. Hey:

I discussed this matter with the Minister. He inquired what had been the practice in the past regarding the assistance granted to the churches in respect to government-owned and church-owned institutions and if the policy was different in regard to the two classes of schools. He expressed the view that it would be interesting to have a statement prepared showing - say over a period of the last five years - what money had been spent in repairs, either directly by the Government or by way of grant to both classes, showing separately the schools operated by the Roman Catholic church and those operated by the other denominations. Would there be much trouble in preparing this statement?

In so far as the particular request is concerned for the repairs to the Spanish Indian Residential School, the last audit statement showing the joint operations of both the boys and girls schools would indicate that they are not being operated at a loss. Under the circumstances, therefore, and in view of the present need for economy, it is thought that the church should be asked to look after this expense.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

RE: Cost of Repairs and Equipment at Government-owned and Church-owned Residential Schools.

In response to the request contained in Mr. Jackson's memorandum of November 25, 1947, I am sending forward herewith a statement of the cost of repairs and equipment at government-owned and church-owned residential schools for the years 1935-36 to 1941-42, inclusive.

We have at this date 77 residential schools in operation, with an authorized pupilage of 6518. Of this number, 27 are church-owned. Five of these are owned by the Anglican Church, one by the United Church of Canada and 21 by the Catholic Church.

There is nothing on record here to indicate that until the year 1936 a distinction has been made throughout the years in respect to the repair and upkeep of church-owned schools on the one hand and the repair and upkeep of government-owned schools on the other. Since 1936 all grants and expenditures for repairs at church-owned schools have been authorized by Order-in-Council. There has been a tendency during the last six years, also, to spend a larger proportion of the funds available on government-owned buildings, with the result of raising the comparatively modern school from rapid deterioration. The funds at our disposal have never been adequate at any time in recent years to keep all our schools in a thorough state of repair. In this connection I may point out that $10,000.00 is provided, annually, by the New England Company for the repair and purchase of equipment at the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ont., and the St. George School, Lytton, B. C. This amount, which is about double what is allowed for repairs and equipment at other schools, has always been fully expended and, in the case of the Mohawk Institute, is scarcely sufficient to keep the school and farm buildings in what one might consider a good state of repair.

Estimates prepared by provincial governments indicate that at mental hospitals with farms attached and at homes for delinquent boys and girls where farms are operated, per capita allowances of between $35.00 and $25.00 per annum is granted for equipment and repairs and usually $1,000.00 per inmate allowed for the construction of new buildings.

From the standpoint of equity, it would be exceedingly difficult to justify lower levels of expenditure on church-owned schools than on schools constructed by the Government, unless compensation was allowed the churches by way of increased per capita grants. For example, the
Fort William Residential School - a church-owned institution with an enrolment of 95 pupils has the lowest per capita allowance ($180.00) of any residential school in the province of Ontario. You will note that the repair costs at this school for the 7 year period amount to $64,234.66 per annum. It would, of course, be wholly impossible to keep an institution such as this in operation if the salaries paid to the teachers and staff of such institutions were paid to the members of the Fort William staff.

The Spanish Residential School, referred to in the memorandum of the Superintendent of Welfare and Training dated November 11, 1942, has at this date an enrolment of 250 pupils and receives a per capita allowance of $180.00 annually. It is interesting, from the standpoint of government expenditures or disbursements, to compare this church-owned school with the Qu'Appelle Residential School - a government-owned institution with an enrolment of 250 pupils. The per capita allowance at this school is $170.00 per annum. The Qu'Appelle School was rebuilt in 1924 at cost to the Government of $100,000.00. This figure includes the cost of the school itself, an addition that was made later, the cost of the land, farm buildings and the cost of equipment. The annual interest charge on this property at 2% amounts to $6,000.00 per annum. Depreciation on fireproof or semi-fireproof buildings is usually allowed at the rate of 1/2% and farm buildings at 5%. If we allow depreciation at Qu'Appelle at the rate of 2% per annum, or $4,000.00, this means an annual charge on government funds amounting to $10,000.00... This works out at $40.00 per pupil, to which we must add an additional amount of $10.00 per pupil, or $50.00 - the amount received by Qu'Appelle over and above the per capita amount received at Spanish. To complete the figure, you will note that the repair costs at Qu'Appelle for the period under review amounted to $46,121.27, or $24.86 per pupil per annum, and at Spanish, $6,302.28, or $25.21 per pupil per annum. In other words, the actual cost to the Department for each pupil now enrolled at Spanish is $163.34 and at Lebret (Qu'Appelle) $234.66, or a difference of $71.32 per pupil per annum. I have selected these two schools for the simple reason that the enrolment at this date is the same. The comparison, I am convinced, might be made with equal results if I had selected such schools as Brandon, Kamloops or Shingwauk or Edmonton. These are all modern buildings where the government outlay has been quite substantial.

In comparing costs at church and government-owned residential schools, one must keep in mind the fact that while government-owned schools and the lands attached thereto are exempt from municipal taxation, church-owned schools and lands enjoy no such exemption. Municipal taxes at such schools as Spanish, Fort William, Squamish, St. Mary's Mission and Neurville are quite substantial. The Squamish School is located in what is virtually a suburb of North Vancouver and the Fort William school in a suburb of Fort William City.

I am attaching hereto a historic sketch of Indian Education prepared a few years ago by Mr. G. M. Matheson, who was for a number of years Head of our Records Branch. At the time of Confederation there were three residential schools in operation in Canada; the Mohawk Institute, built and maintained by the New England Company.
of London, England; the Mount Elgin Institute, Canada, built by the Wesleyan Missionary Society and supported by this society and by contributions from India; some others such as Wabamun's Residential School (non-Spanish) built and maintained by the Jesuit Order.

Under the British North America Act the Dominion Government became wholly responsible for Indian education, but this responsibility was assumed very gradually and has never at any time been fully assumed. For example, it was not until 1895 that the Government established residential schools in western Canada. However, since 1867 the Government has always worked closely with the churches of Canada in promoting a worthwhile Indian educational program, but the Indian educational policy of the Government has never been clearly defined. From the outset, it appears the Government assisted the Churches in the repair and maintenance of schools and permitted the Church to become wholly responsible for the administration and operation of residential schools and, in addition, extended to the Bishop of the Catholic and Anglican Churches and to the Home Mission Board of the United and Presbyterian Churches the right, in certain cases, to nominate Indian day school teachers. This policy, or lack of policy, has never been wholly satisfactory either from the standpoint of the Government or from the standpoint of the Churches. The practice followed has created from time to time a number of somewhat delicate and difficult situations and problems. It is just possible that the time has arrived when the whole policy and practice of Indian educational effort might be very carefully reviewed.
Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ontario,

March 1, 1943.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I am forwarding to you enclosed the claim sheet in duplicate for the purchase of the gyproc and for the carpenter's labour to date.

In your letter of February 4th (36-0-5) you stated that there will be a balance of $300 after paying for the gyproc. Deducting from this the wages already paid for labour ($92.00) leaves I think $208.46. This I would like to apply in part to buying logs, and in part for the carpenter's labour. We need a lot of lumber for the repairs necessary. To buy the lumber necessary would run into a good deal. Our intention is to buy just logs instead. We ourselves will saw the logs. By so doing we can, we expect, get our lumber for about $18.00 (eighteen dollars) a thousand. We have been trying to come to a satisfactory agreement with one of the lumber men of the district but are still awaiting his final reply. Have we your approval of applying the balance in this twofold way?

Yours very truly,

C.A. Primeau, S.J.

Dear Father Primeau:

Reporting on his inspection of the Spanish Indian Residential School on June 14th, Mr. McNamara writes as follows:

"The Boys' Playroom and toilets are badly in need of repair. The toilets are not properly partitioned off from the playroom. The result is that the latter place has not a very healthy atmosphere for recreational purposes.

Dear Father Primeau:

You will recall my discussing with you and later writing you regarding the possibility of our renewing the sagged springs from some of our beds at residential schools.

Dear Mr. Arneil,

My first duty is to apologize to you for not acknowledging sooner your letters and effort to assist us in the matter of bed springs. I hope that you will forgive me—there has been no malice in my tardiness—just a case of not getting it done, though I had asked our workman to do it several times. Today I finally went up myself and the spring which I am forwarding under separate cover is the result.

You asked for the inside measurements of the bed frame. The most common size, which can also be adapted to fit smaller ones, is 67 inches long by 32 inches wide. That is the inside measurements of the frame of the bed spring.

Thank you, sincerely, for all your trouble in this matter. I do hope that the spring we are sending will be what you desired.

With kindest wishes,

Yours sincerely,

(Rev.) G.A. Primeau, S.J.

Dear Mr Phelan,

As you know I am very new at this job and unfortunately Father Primeau could not stay long enough for a comprehensive transfer of the business. I would much appreciate your advice on several counts.

In a letter in the files dated March 10th 1946 Father Primeau asks that the balance of the funds available for repairs and improvements in the school for the then closing fiscal year should be applied to the purchase of white ready mixed paint for inside painting. The paint came in April and was used. On the thirtieth of July we received a bill from the Canadian Industries Limited in which the paint is billed as... Sold to... Department of Mines and Resources Shipped to Rev C.A. Primeau Principal Indian Residential School Spanish. As there is no return letter from your office on file with the one mentioned written by Father Primeau on March 10th I thought best to ask about it. Do we simply write out a voucher and send the voucher to the company along with their bills or do we send voucher and bills to the Department? The bill amounts to $203.35. Memorandum: MR. PHELAN.

Re: Inspection of North Bay, Spanish, Manitoulin Island, Shingwauk Home and Longlac.

XX XX XX

SPANISH GIRLS.

The great part of the children were down with the mumps. At the time of my visit, however, the school was back to normal again.

The school is very neat and in good repair. The children appear happy, healthy and satisfied. All the children are lovely singers.

The primary room is making good progress. The children love to read and are neat in their work. They do a great deal of dramatization; this is a great help for children who are learning a strange language. They know a large number of songs and they take delight in singing them. This class is under the direction of Miss Breau.

The intermediate class is under the direction of Miss S. Michel. She is not a qualified teacher. She is, however, sympathetic to the children and very conscientious in her work.

The senior room, under the direction of Miss Whelan is doing splendid work. The integrated system of education has been tried in this room. She has integrated silk, rayon, cotton and wool with history and social reforms. The children are in general, good readers and enjoy reading from the library books.

The sewing class is obtaining experience from repair work and the cutting and sewing of their own clothing. They do a great deal of knitting. A number of machines at this school are in bad shape and should be replaced as soon as possible.

XX XX XX

As J. Doucet,
Training Division.
There is definitely a fire trap in this building. The furnace is situated immediately below the chain of stairs. Should a fire break out this might result in trapping a certain number of students. The fire escapes built of metal poles would be of very little help in cold weather, especially for smaller children. An outside closed in stairway could, very easily be provided at about blocks and should give exit to each floor. I would recommend that a night watchman be employed.

Reverend Father Oliver, Principal, is very keen and has broad views on education. I would expect the school to make definite progress under his guidance.

Memorandum: MR. PHILAN.

Re: inspection of North Bay, Spanish, Manitoulin Island, Shingwauk Home and Longlac.

XX XX XX

SPANISH

I believe the complaints re clothing, food and cleanliness are unfounded. The children seem happy, well-clothed and appear in good physical condition. The clothing misunderstanding appears to be caused by the actions of some parents. When parents visit their children, special articles of clothing are sometimes given. This induces some of the other pupils to write to their parents in order to obtain similar clothing. This evidently creates a bad impression on some of the Reserves.

The Principal seems to think that it would be better for the school to grant the discharge of these pupils. This, however, might create a bad precedent. I would then advise that the request for the discharge of these pupils be refused and that they should complete the term. I intrusted the Principal to notify this office immediately should there be any further trouble.

The primary room in this school is overcrowded. There are over sixty pupils. Grades one, two and three are in this division along with the beginners. In General, these pupils have very little, if any knowledge of the English language. This is an impossible task.

This school should have at least four classrooms. It is rather difficult for the Principal to organize another classroom due to the necessity of engaging another teacher. As conditions are at present, the Principal is having, I believe, a difficult time making his accounts balance. It is my belief, however, that something definite should be done to remedy this situation.

The Principal is endeavouring to obtain a qualified Manual Training teacher. He has one in mind, but has not yet received a definite answer from him. This would relieve the crowded situation to some extent. The situation should be studied now in view to improve conditions for next term.

A new teacher has been engaged this year, but as he was sick, I was unable to meet him.

XX XX XX

A.J. Doucet,
Training Division.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

In reference to your letter of March 15th regarding the special appropriation for improvements and repairs.

The girls' section have proposed the following work which is very necessary at their school:

1. The labour involved in glazing and painting 194 windows of various sizes.
2. The labour involved in painting 16 rooms and repairing the plaster in same.

These two items will without doubt from the point of view of labor only, take care of the share of the appropriation allotted to the Girls' Department. The estimated cost of the work (excluding material) being approximately $500 dollars.

At the Boys' School we realize fully the fire hazard. We had planned on putting up a cement structure outside the building, which would serve as an ordinary stairway to dormitory, study hall and recreation hall, and prove at the same time a very practical fire escape. We had planned to pay part of the labor from the appropriation and to manage the materials from our ordinary grant. With prices soaring on such very vital equipment such as brooms and glass and with the possibility of everything going higher we are best to keep within our means. We have another fire escape of the stairs type which we shall have placed at the end of the building where we had planned to build the cement one. It will be the second escape for the main dormitory and will obviate the necessity of the younger children using the pole in winter. We ourselves regret that we cannot follow out the first plan which...
from every point of view would have been far more practical.

Last year the camp was partially completed but the outside of the buildings was not done. We shall have this work done this year. The same holds for the cannery; either ship lap or heavy braced paper will have to be used. Our green house is practically finished. It was necessary here due to the fact that such plants as tomatoes had to have an early start they are one of the main vegetables for the children throughout the winter.

If we may we should like to use our share of the appropriation for the finishing off of the jobs mentioned above, and for the installing of the fire escape also mentioned above.

Dear Father Oliver:

As you are aware, there was an amount provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements amounting to $1,700. You sent me cheques as follows -

$57.00  $179.80  $142.50

I was checking with the Treasury this morning and find that we have already paid all the accounts for the paint. I am, therefore, returning your cheques. Dear Mr. Phelan;

In reference to extra labour grants for the year...with the balance left to them the Girls' Department has advised that they would wish to use it for the painting of class rooms and lavatories and for the glazing of windows.

At our school we have had to undertake the expense of pointing the whole building, a job which has been put off for several years. The first estimate given us was around three thousand dollars. We had no choice but to give it to a contractor from the Sault working on a cost plus basis. If there were any chance of getting help in this matter we would be very grateful. The increased per capita will safely look after the "up" in the cost of living I think and the salaries demanded by federation teachers who are qualified. We are using the mill and electric shop and our power house for shop work but must fix up, and will, an equipped shop in the basement, the other places are not suitable in winter and for other various reasons.

Would you please advise us as to any possibility of our getting any financial help in the pointing business...in any case we would appreciate knowing the balances left for each of the schools, and have permission to apply these balances as mentioned above...they for the painting and glazing we for the pointing of the house.

Dear Mr. Neary:

In reference to your letter of the 16th June and further reference to ours of the 11th, regarding repairs.

For the Boys Section the main repair this year is the pointing of the building which is progressing well. We should like to use our share of the grant for this.

We have begun the shop for the auto mechanics and electrical courses. It is being built in the basement with considerable expense involved. New lighting, three new walls painting etc.

The third item will be the construction of a new drive shed in a more suitable spot and sufficiently large to house all the farm instruments.

I name the three items because we may have to apply for reclaim on one or the other depending on the stress at the time. I understand of course that the grant total is as specified in your letter to a total of $1700 dollars for both schools.

Ottawa, February 11, 1946.

Memorandum:

Classroom Inspection Report - Spanish Girls' Residential School.

Due to the fact that the girls had been attending school on the full day basis for some years now, they tested very well on the Achievement Tests administered.

There are four classrooms in operation, all in charge of qualified teachers. I found the condition of this school excellent and the girls well mannered and very willing to speak out and show what they can do. The High School class is exceptionally good and several of them are interested in nursing and teaching careers.

The Principal of the school, Miss Z. St. James has been teaching Indians for forty-six years and has a keen appreciation of what can and what cannot be done with these pupils.

This building is definitely superior to that of the boys' section and has been well maintained by Miss Z. St. James and her predecessors.
RECOMMENDATIONS:

1. That the boys and girls should be sent to either the Provincial School at Massey or to North Bay for their Grade eleven when they have passed Grade Ten.

2. That we investigate the possibility of finding foster homes on Manitoulin Island for children of seven and eight years old so as to allow for an increase in pupilage next year. These children could attend the local day schools and thus permit a certain number of High School pupils to remain for another year.

3. That we provide a mimeograph machine for the girls' section of this school.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education,

BFN/IM.
Ottawa, February 11, 1948.

Memorandum:

Classroom Inspection Report -
Spanish Boys' Residential School.

I only spent half a day at this school and my report is, therefore, very sketchy. I observed four of them and found the boys very willing and interested in their work. Three of the teachers are qualified. As a result of the half day system with the older boys, the Achievement tests compared only fairly well. Now what this system has been abolished, more rapid progress should be made by this section of the school.

Father Oliver is keenly interested in both the classroom and the extra-curricular activities of this school and is quite willing to have the boys now in Grade ten and eleven attend the Massey High School.

Bernard Z. Henry,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Mr Phelan...

Mr Neary asked if we had given any line up of the work to be done this year which might be helped by the grant covering extra labour.

At the Girls Section they wish to have the windows of the whole house glazed, they intend to paint class rooms which have not been done and have extensive repairs on their roof draining system, sewers, troughing. This would be nearly a thousand dollars and any grant given will be halved since the two sections are doing work which is necessary and vital.

At the Boys School we have had a good deal of repairs done in plumbing and this is the first year we have got through without continual complaints about the recreation hall toilet system and the connections from that place to the septic tank. The work is not finished but the good part of it is over. We have an unpaid bill of $230.70, of which materials amount to $236.50 and the labour $794.20, with Jas Solomon Plumbers Sudbury. We would like very much to be able to apply whatever the grant is to the labour part of this bill which is dated in the current year since some of the work was done after Christmas. This is an incredible bill for plumbing but these are incredible times. You may be well assured that we have no other big projects on for this year! The work done has been held over for years. I see some rather urgent letters in the files from the Department about the conditions formerly existing. Hope this can be arranged as it means a good deal to us. We would pay immediately and get that settled.

Sincerely,

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT,

Spanish Residential School,

You are of course aware of our scale of issue of supplies and services for government-owned Indian residential schools.

We have received a receipted account covering the cost of a milking machine purchased for use at the Spanish Indian Residential School. This is a church-owned school and there are funds in the current year's appropriation to pay this account.

The boys at this school are now in classrooms for the full day and not for a half day, as formerly. The school is well operated and has always maintained splendid herds to supply milk for the children. Dear Mr. Phelan;

It does not seem difficult since the schools run as a unit on the repaired grant. I wish you to be assured that we notified early in the year as regards the grants and will do the same as soon as we have news after April 1st so that the Girls School may again have the opportunity of planning on the work. Dear Father Oliver:

In the appropriation for the fiscal year 1949-50 there was included a total amount of $5,000.00 for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at the Spanish Residential School. However, there were two accounts held over from last year amounting in all to $581.48. This leaves a balance of $4,418.52.

As you are aware, there has only been made available half of our appropriation, and the balance of the appropriation will be voted when Parliament resumes its session in September.

There have been no definite instructions to the effect that we must only spend half of the amount at each school, and as many of the schools do not require their money until later in the year, we could possibly handle in your case the total amount mentioned above at any time. I suggest that you give the matter your consideration, and decide in what manner you wish the money spent. We would appreciate it if you would communicate with us before spending any money, as it is always easier for us to have expenditures approved before they are incurred.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

In further reference to yours of June 2nd 1949, in which there is mention of a grant balance of $4,418.58, the half of which is now available to the schools here etc...

We notice that the sum seems to include "purchase of new equipment" and since we know that not all new equipment expenditures would be approved, (there was the case of the milking machines)...for reasons dictated by the policy to be followed in the Department, we would like to know about the possibility of help on the buying of a hay baler. We figure the price as around $2200.00 and would like if possible to apply $1000.00 dollars of the improvement grant to that purpose.

The farm is extensive and labor is difficult to get, and when you do get men the price is exorbitant for farm work. There are never more than one or two of the bigger boys left, we have two brothers who must handle all of the farm work in the summer, and during the month's camping, when we staff the Ayrd Island Camp fully and have the boys go there, the problem is still greater. We have to buy hay each year. With the baler we could buy the fields and do a quick and efficient job all round and the baler would pay for itself in three years. With a better farm better food. We got a tractor last year and it has already proved its worth. We shall be very anxious to hear from you in this regard since we should have to order early.

Very sincerely yours,

To the Superintendent of Indian Affairs

Dear Sir,

I have just received a communication from the Indian Residential School, signed by Mr. Smith, Director, Spanish Creek, which I enclose herewith.

As I was just preparing to have him come back, although it is a difficult matter for me at present—but I am expecting a position soon—I received a letter dated the 3rd of June informing me that my son had lost a finger cut off from his principal hand, that is the right one.

I am very sorry of that. I sent my child to Spain without any regard, he will return here without a finger that will be missing all through his future life.

I have no detail yet but he must be seriously wounded and if such is the case I will hold you responsible or the community for having sent my child to work in a dangerous position who might have imperiled his life. A child of less than 15 years on a sawing machine I suppose.

Hoping that you will hold a strict investigation as I am anxiously awaiting your report and information as to whether the boy is seriously wounded or finger completely off. We expect a good settlement. It will not be pleasant to see my child return wounded. This is intolerable. I await your reply.

Yours,

[Signature]

Reverend Sir,

I desire to refer to previous correspondence with reference to the discharge of Paul Henri Gros-Louis from the Spanish Indian Residential School.

The Department is now in receipt of a letter from his father, stating that he has just been advised regarding the boy losing a finger on the 3rd instant. It is noted that you reported this in your letter of the 4th instant.

Please let the Department have full details regarding this accident as soon as possible. You should state how the boy was employed when it occurred, whether he was under the supervision of any member of the staff at the time and whether or not there was any carelessness on his own part. Please let me know, also, if this boy lost the whole or only part of his finger and advise his condition at the present time and when the medical officer considers he will be able to go home.

Ottawa, November 23, 1933.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, requesting that dental attention be given to the pupils of the Spanish Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange with Dr. W. E. Boyd, Espanola, Ont., to perform the dental work absolutely urgent at the present time. The work should be done at the school. Owing to the extremely limited funds available for dental services, the total expenditure incurred for the treatment of the Spanish School must not exceed the sum of $200. Dr. Boyd will be allowed the same rates as previously paid him, viz.: $1.00 per amalgam filling; 50¢ in the case of each extraction of permanent teeth; and 25¢ for each extraction of first teeth. In the case of first teeth, no dental attention with the exception of extraction can be allowed. Dr. Boyd is to supply all materials and he will be allowed his actual travelling expenses. I would request that the new pupils entering the school receive first consideration by the dentist.

Please have Dr. Boyd prepare a list, in triplicate, on a medical account form, stating the name of each pupil receiving attention and the number of fillings and extractions in each case. You should also state thereon the mileage travelled by him and the amount charged, which must not exceed 7¢ per mile. This account should be certified by you and forwarded to the Department for payment.

You may arrange for the carrying out of the dental work absolutely urgent at the present time. This should be done at an early date, but it should be distinctly understood that the total cost is not to exceed the amount stated above, viz.: $200.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Reverend Paul Nery, S. J.,
Principal,

Ottawa, December 27, 1904.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, enclosing a communication which you received from Dr. W. H. Boyd, Spanish, Ont., regarding dental attention required by the pupils of the Spanish Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have to say that you may arrange with Dr. Boyd to perform the dental work absolutely urgent at the present time for the pupils at the Boys' and Girls' Schools. The Department will allow Dr. Boyd remuneration at the rate of $30 per day and reasonable travel expenses. The work should be performed at the school—the dentist to supply all materials. It is considered that not more than 5 days' work should be necessary at this time. The Department is now paying dentists at a per diem rate instead of, as formerly, a fee for each extraction and filling.

It is expected that the dentist will devote full time to the work while at the school, and you should assist him in having the pupils ready for treatment, in order that there will be no delay in his work.

The dentist should prepare a list, showing the name of each pupil receiving treatment and the work performed in each case. He should also prepare an account for his services at the rate mentioned. The account, with the list of work done, should be handed to you, to be certified in the usual manner and forwarded to the Department for payment.

It is noted that Dr. Boyd will be able to perform the dental work early in the new year. Our funds are extremely limited, and it is considered that five days should be sufficient to carry out all the work required by the pupils at the present time.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

**CANADA**
October 21st, 1935

Dear Sir:

Some dental work is required at the Indian Residential School at Spanish. The girls have been examined recently by one of the departmental nurses, Miss B. Cousins, who finds that something in the neighbourhood of 100 fillings are likely to be required. She did not examine the boys, but I think it likely that 3 or 4 days' work will be required. The Department now allows a rate of $50.00 per day for clinic work of this nature, plus all out of pocket expenses.

It is intended that Miss Cousins should return to Spanish at an early date, and I hope it will be possible for you to conduct the clinic when she is there to assist.

At Serpent River Reserve, which is about 8 miles north of Spanish, there are 15 or 20 children requiring dental attention. The Department is willing to authorize a one-day clinic there, with the understanding that school children shall be given the preference but that adults in urgent need of dental service should receive attention if time allows on the day set for the clinic. Miss Cousins will arrange the clinic there with the cooperation of the school teacher. I would suggest Friday, October 25th, for the work at Serpent River, and October 26th, 27th and 28th for the residential schools at Spanish.

W.E. Boyd, Esq., D.D.S.,
Espanola,
Ontario.
Miss Cousins is at present working in the vicinity of Sault Ste. Marie. I am instructing her to arrange for a clinic at Serpent River at school on Friday, as soon as she hears from you. I presume you will be able to notify her not later than October 23rd, as to whether you will be able to undertake this work or not. Her address is - c/o Mr. Indian Agent Sims, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

If you are not able to undertake this work mentioned above, please notify the Department at Ottawa and Miss Cousins at Sault Ste. Marie, immediately.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes
Acting Secretary
October 31st, 1935

Reverend Sir:

From the report of Miss Cousins, the Departmental nurse who was recently assigned for duty at Spanish, I find that many of the pupils in the girls' school require dental attention. I have requested Doctor Boyd to arrange to do this work immediately and have suggested October 28-29-30. Miss Cousins has been instructed to return to Spanish to assist at this clinic and while she is there I think it would be of considerable benefit to have her examine the pupils of the boys' school. She will know whether they require dental attention or not.

Doctor Boyd's accounts for services to pupils in the Spanish Residential Schools will be submitted through you in the regular way. The rate which is now allowed for clinic work is $30.00 per day, plus out of pocket expenses.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes
Acting Secretary

Reverend Paul Mery,
Principal,

October 26th, 1935

Reverend Sir:

I am requesting Doctor Harvie to examine pupils of the Girls School who were reported by the nurse as having enlarged tonsils. It may be that some of these require operation, and possibly some of the boys require similar attention.

Miss Moodie has mentioned the excellent infirmary accommodation at Spanish, and if there are a number of pupils requiring tonsillectomy this would seem to be a favourable time to have the work done as the Department is willing to assign Miss Beatrice Cousins for full time duty at the school for a few days and also to authorize Doctor Harvie to engage a nurse from Espanola if a tonsil clinic can be arranged at Spanish. Our suggestion is that Doctor Harvie's time should be conserved by Miss Cousins making the general examination and referring cases to him for his decision. She is a very competent nurse and a good organizer, and I feel that the clinic can be arranged without disturbing school routine for any pupils save the patients, and every effort would be made to avoid disturbance of the staff.

Doctor Harvie and Miss Cousins are being requested to hold themselves in readiness to organize the suggested clinic if you have no objection. They will consult with you and Miss St. James and the final decision as to whether the clinic will be held at the Residential School or not rests with you. The suggested arrangement is, however, the only one for which funds are available at present.

I wish to make it clear that it is not necessary to consult the Department further in this connection, as the work should done immediately, if at all, in order to take advantage of the fact that Miss Cousins is in your district.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Reverend Father Mary,
Principal, Residential School,
Spanish, Ont.

T. R. L. MacInnes
Acting Secretary

October 26th, 1935

Dear Sir:

In the report of Nurse Cousins of her examination of the girls at Spanish Residential School, 5 are mentioned as having enlarged tonsils. She did not examine the boys at the time of her first visit, but it is likely that the same report could be made about at least as many of them.

Will you please arrange to go to Spanish during the coming week, with a view to planning a tonsil clinic at the School if this is found to be necessary. It is expected that Miss Cousins will be on duty there the first three or four days of the week, as a dental clinic has been planned. We are not absolutely certain of the dates, as the details of arrangement were left to Doctor Boyd and Miss Cousins. I would suggest that you ascertain from the School authorities or Doctor Boyd when the dental work is completed, as we do not wish to impose on the good nature of the Principal by disorganizing his school routine too greatly.

I have written Reverend Father Méry, telling him that we wish to conserve your time by having Miss Cousins make the general examination of pupils and referring those requiring attention to you, on the occasion of your visit at the school. I have made it clear to him that the decision as to whether a clinic should be held at the school or not rests with him. The Department is

H.H. Harvie, Esq., M.D.,
Espanola
Ont.
willing to assign Miss Cousins to full time duty for a few days, and is willing also to authorize you to engage a nurse from Espanola to remain at the School with Nurse Cousins for a few days if the clinic takes place. I presume Doctor Berry would give the anaesthetics, and it is desired that he or you should remain at the School over night as a precautionary measure.

You may not find that there are a sufficient number of pupils requiring tonsillectomy to justify the proposed clinic, in which case the idea may be dropped for the present as funds are not available to carry it out under other circumstances.

On the occasion of your preliminary visit in this connection, please examine all pupils reported as having sore eyes. Miss Cousins will be able to give you their names. I should also like to have a report from you regarding goitre in the Schools and the possibility of treatment.

The Department wishes to take advantage of Miss Cousins' presence in the district, and it is desirable that as much work as possible should be done not only for the pupils of the Residential Schools but for the Indians in all Reserves under your care.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes
Acting Secretary

November 8, 1935

Department Of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sirs:

In connection with the tonsil clinic recently held at the Residential School, Spanish, I wish to point out the extra effort, time and expense it meant to me.

Firstly, I made a trip and inspected some 50 prospective cases on Nov. 1st.

Secondly, I made a trip on Nov. 2nd to carry out the operations and remained in the School overnight leaving at noon on November 3rd.

Thirdly, it was necessary for Dr. Berry to take a second car in order to return to Espanola the same day as the practice was left alone all day, so this meant a trip for him to give anaesthetics.

Fourthly, I borrowed a bundle of sterilized sponges from Hospital here which were returned, borrowed all necessary instruments also McKesson suction and ether vaporizer apparatus and head light from Hospital and burned out a bulb of head light, used about 10 or 11 feet of Hospital #8 snare wire, used 3 Ethyl Chloride 100 grams tubes and ½ lb. chloroform of my own, took my own sterilized gowns, and also took hemostatic serum, horse serum, cat-gut and linen for emergencies but were not necessary to use.

I have indicated the above as I believe you will agree it is only fair I should receive some remuneration other than the $50.00 anaesthetic fees for Dr. Berry's services.

Yours truly,

Dr. H. H. Harvie.

November 8, 1935

Department Of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sirs:

I have your letter of Oct. 26/35 No. 36-0-13D and carried out your requests.

I visited the Spanish Residential School on Nov. 1st, and made arrangements for a tonsil clinic the following day Nov. 2nd. On Nov. 2nd we performed ten tonsillectomies on 6 boys & 4 girls in the Girls' Infirmary. There are still remaining about 35 cases that some day would be the better for being done. I remained at the School overnight as requested. In fact, I was at the School Nov. 1st, 2nd, 3rd., 6th, and 7th, so far this month.

I examined 18 cases of sore eyes Miss Cousins had picked out and I believe found 8 positive cases of trachoma amongst the boys and 10 other suspicious ones and 6 suspicious ones amongst the girls. One boy had a particularly bad eye and I thought it better to isolate him from the rest to see how he responds to treatment and to await word from the Department as to whether you wish anything further done. His eye was discharging considerably, his lids were acutely congested and he had a history of possible trachoma in the family. We have instituted treatment for all eighteen. The boys' school does not seem to have the necessary supplies so I suggested they borrow sufficient from the Girls' School until the Department have time to send some to them.

There are about 50 cases of enlarged thyroid in each school and I have suggested that each school requisition for 5000 Sodium Iodide tablets on arrival of which we will commence treatment for them. Sometime ago I had the Girls' School requisition for them but the Department at that time replied that they did not supply them but I hope you will now.

I would like to pass a few remarks re Miss Cousins'.
