November 5th, 1935

Dear Sir:

There has been considerable discussion of the services and compensation of Doctors Harvie and Langlois at Espanola and Blind River respectively. Doctor Harvie receives a salary of $2000 per annum for attendance on the Spanish River and Serpent River Reserves and at the Indian Residential School. It is not found that he has rendered any accounts for extra services to these people but he has rendered some accounts for work done for Indians not belonging to any of these groups. Doctor Langlois receives $600 for attendance at Blind River and he has rendered many accounts for other Indians including some for those of Serpent River.

It was, without doubt, the Department's intention that the salaries paid these two doctors should cover all professional services rendered by them to Indians and the Department means to adhere to this intention both as regards accounts which may now be unpaid and as regards the future. Kindly communicate this information to the doctors concerned.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie

September 30th, 1936

Dear Sir:

Miss St. James writes the Department that she did not receive enough gauze in her last requisition and that some other items asked for were not supplied. On this she mentioned Hypodermic needles and syringes. It is believed that between the two schools there may be sufficient supplies of this kind on hand to last until larger regular order is sent in. I must say that the requisitions from your schools are often not very carefully made up and show little sign of examination by the medical officer. Such an item, for example as "suture sundries and forceps" gives little indication of what is required; in fact several items were deleted because it was not clear what was wanted and others such as Bicarbonate of Soda because it was scarcely thought the Department should be asked to supply it.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie

Reverend Sir:

This will be your authority to arrange for a dental clinic at the Spanish Indian Residential School. The work is to be offered to Doctor W. E. Boyd, of Espanola, and the fee allowed is $30.00 per day, the dentist to provide his own materials for extractions and simple fillings. A maximum of six days' work is authorized by this letter. If this does not nearly cover the requirements it might be possible to have another clinic in the fall. Probably you will not wish to have more than this number of days done at the present time.

Doctor Boyd may be allowed actual return railway fare from Espanola to Spanish to compensate him for his outlay in travelling. It is assumed that he will be accommodated at the school without charge.

It is not necessary that the account should contain the names of pupils treated but the number of fillings and extractions must be given. You will wish to keep a record of the work done for each pupil.

November 12, 1937.

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,

Dear Sir:

All children in the villages about here have been inoculated for diphtheria, scarlet fever and small-pox. It is the general opinion that the boys and girls of the Indian School ought to be treated likewise.

The opinion is emphasized now that a neighbor's child has died and a report from Toronto shows that the cause of death was diphtheria.

I would urge that our children be inoculated here as we are not prepared for an epidemic.

Yours truly,

J. Howitt

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6219, file 471-13, part 2)
Reverend Sir,

In reply to your letter of November 12th, I may say that the Department wishes as you do to avoid an outbreak of diphtheria at the school under your charge. You do not say, however, whether the proposed measure is inoculation with diphtheria antitoxin as a temporary measure, or treatment by toxoid as a permanent protection. The latter is preferable, for obvious reasons, if there is no apparent immediate danger.

This is a matter to be taken up with Doctor Harvie, but not for further correspondence. He will scarcely expect an additional fee for the work, and he can procure the necessary materials. If so asked, you may accept an account from the Provincial Government or other usual source of supply.

Yours truly,

T.R.L. MacInnes,

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of May 17, I may say that I do not think that the supply of rubbing alcohol to the Spanish Residential School need be limited by the fact that your allowance is consumed in your own practice. Your registration number must be quoted on the requisition for the School drug supplies. Why the Principal should have ordered rubbing alcohol from a firm in Toronto is not clear. So that there may be no further difficulty, the Department is quite prepared to take care of the whole matter, if you will let me know what your permit number is. 20 August, 1938.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Dear Sir:

Isaac Thompson 1076 is expected to die within a few days of tubercular meningitis and his mother phoned that she would like the body sent to her at the following address:
Mrs Catherine Lacore, # Sandy Rouselle, R.R. 1 Box 20, Cornwall, Ontario.

Does the Department approve of this, or shall we bury the boy at the school?
An early answer would be appreciated.

Yours truly,

J. Howitt.
Ottawa, August 25, 1938.

Reverend Sir:

In acknowledgment of your letter of the 20th instant, reporting the gravity of the illness of Isaac Thompson, I wish to state that the suggestion to send the body home, if the boy should die, has received sympathetic consideration. I have to point out, however, that it is not the practice of the Department to send bodies of Indians by rail excepting under very exceptional circumstances. Bodies so shipped have to be properly prepared by the undertakers for transshipment under the laws of the province, and the expense of a long journey, such as this would be, would entail an expenditure which the Department does not feel warranted in authorizing.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Rev. J. Howitt, S.J.,
Principal,
Spanish Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ontario.

To the Secretary

Dear Sir:

I had the visit today of Paul Henry Grosouis, who until some five years back resided with his father in Montreal. At that time his father died, and being an orphan, on his father's and mother's side, he has more or less lived the life of trying to make his own living, which he has succeeded to the best of his ability, staying most of these years in the United States of America; consequently has done what most of the Indians don't by looking after himself without the Department's help.

He is yet a poor man at that, and married in Los Angeles, Cal., and has been a sailor aboard steamships. Now here's the object of this letter. In 1930 your Department sent him to St. Peter Claver Indian School at Spanish, Ont., where he resided two years, or until July 1932, where he met with an accident, losing one whole finger and joint, the index in the right hand, while working in the saw mills. After being discharged from the hospital he was sent back home to Montreal, where his father placed a complaint, intending to see for damages.

At the time I understand your Department asked the father to hold this until the boy was fully of age, meaning the twenty-one year mark.

You had his visit last week, and according to his statement, you referred him to his own agency, to take this matter up from here. This man claims he is entitled to some damages, as it has lost a number of jobs for him, and wants you to allow him a decent amount at once, so he can move back to his wife and kids. I would be obliged, if you would give this letter quick consideration, and advise of your intentions.

Respectfully,

[Signature]

The Doctor visiting the school is pleased with the state of health of our children. We attribute this success to the use of cod liver oil. In spite of the welfare, the oil procures to the Girls, we are ready to change the way of serving it though we do not think it would be so efficacious.

Yours Truly,

Dear Doctor:

I take the liberty to acquaint you of the measures I took since early December to obtain Cod Liver Oil.

This tonic does a great good to our girls and I wish to do all I can to get it for them.

Having received no answer to our letter giving details required by yours of December 14th I wish to know if it is your will that we do without it though early Spring is the time they need it most. If we had known we could not get any more we would not have given them any in the Fall.

Believe me, dear Doctor,

Yours very truly

January 28, 1939.

Dear Sir:

The Department has again been approached over the amount of Cod Liver Oil supplied to the Spanish Indian Residential School in the present year.

Long standing instructions prescribe a dose of one teaspoonful of Cod Liver Oil twice daily to every pupil in an Indian residential school during the six months of cold weather. This is provided by an issue of one gallon of Cod Liver Oil for each four pupils. If this were exceeded, the Department could not meet more than a small part of the demand.

Your school received its amounts of oil on this basis, and further supplies cannot be expected during the course of the present school year.

Yours truly,

H. L. Stone, M.B.,
Superintendent of Medical Services.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

We have a few girls suffering from swollen tonsils, but one of them, Lila Thompson, is really in a very poor condition. Would it be permitted to send her to the hospital to be operated? Dr. Gibbon, Dr. Harris's assistant, saw her; he thinks as we do but says he is not permitted to do it.

I also took upon myself to get glasses for Rose Frank, who is discharged though she is still here as we can't find her family. While she was in school all day she could put her book a few inches from her sight, but now we put her in the vocational class and she can hardly see a cup three feet from her.

Trusting this will meet with your approval,

Yours sincerely,

Clotilde Laferriere

October 18, 1940.

Dear Sir:

We have received a letter, copy of which is enclosed, from the Principal of the Girls' Section of the Spanish Residential School.

It will be in order for you to arrange to have Lila Simpson attended to by the doctor, and if a tonsillectomy is necessary it may be proceeded with, that is, if permission is obtained from her parents or guardians.

The Principal mentions getting glasses for Rosie Frank. We are enclosing copy of our latest circular in this regard and in future we wish the instructions set forth therein followed. Under the circumstances, it seems apparent that Rosie Frank was badly in need of glasses and, therefore, in this instance we will authorize their purchase. Is there any possibility that the parents of this child might pay part of the expense of these glasses?

Yours truly,

Dear Sirs:

As there is an epidemic of whooping cough in the country surrounding St. Joseph's Residential School, Spanish, I would suggest that all the pupils in that school be given the regular immunization with pertussis vaccine.

There are about 250 pupils and it would be necessary to arrange for an adequate supply of vaccine for this purpose, should you approve.

The Secretary  
Indian Affairs Branch  
Dept. of Mines and Resources  
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear sir;

We are again asking for the following articles and drugs. They were requested in June, 1941, but were never received. When Doctor Faulkner made his official visit this year, we informed him of this and he intimated that we should again make a request for them. We carefully explained to him our particular need of these items, herein listed.

1- Head band & Mirror  
1- Dental probe, R & L curve  
1- Dental mirror  
12- Rolls adhesive tape, 2 x 10  
4- Bolts plain gauge  
15- Cases of Thalattol or Cod Liver oil

It might be well to state again our need for these articles. The head band and mirror is needed to make preliminary examination of patient, before phoning doctor, who is residing 35 miles from the school. In all cases the doctor always tries to find out as much information as possible before deciding what is best to done to boy. Without the head band and mirror we are often at a lost to answer his questions.

Concerning the dental instruments our difficulty is much
It is necessary for us to make the preliminary examination of the boys' teeth before making report to Dept. for visit of Dentist and moreover, we have to treat toothaches at the school. It would be impossible as well as very costly to have to run every boy with a toothache to the dentist, who lives 35 miles from the school.

Our need for adhesive tape and guaze is also very great. This year we only received two rolls of 2 x 10 tape, which has already been used up. Last year we experienced the same difficulty and as a result we had to buy an addition supply. This year we have again bought an extra two rolls, which we last us for another month or two. We have also had to sew on all dressings or else tie them with sheeting. When we explained this to the Doctor, he informs us that the Dept. could buy this material cheaper than our school. Likewise for the guaze, we have to use a lot of this material, due to the fact that Indian children are often troubled with skin disease. This year's supply is about used up.

This year's supply of cod liver oil will last us only about 3½ months. Rationing out the oil to 125 boys, a case lasts us from 8 to 10 days. To get good and lasting results from the oil for the year we should start now to issue it, but if we do so, we will have used our supply before the middle of the year. We should especially give oil to the boys in the Spring as well as Fall and half the winter months. But to do this we would need at least 15 more cases. Last year we had very good results from the little supply we had on hand. But we found out we started too late and had to stop too early in the year, to enable us to obtain the very best results and less sickness.

Hoping you will give this request your kindest consideration we remain,

Yours truly,

Mr. Philip Phalen,

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phalen:

One of our pupils, Rita Maracle, is apparently suffering from some type of mental illness, and we should like to have arrangements made for placing her in some institution where she could be given necessary attention.

This child was sent here from an orphanage at Kingston, Ont., on July 10, 1940. She is sixteen years of age. She has had no correspondence from parents or relatives since her arrival, and we have no records as to her parents' home address, etc.

She has always seemed to be of a very morose disposition. Since September...
First, she has become more and more troublesome, until it has become necessary to remove her from contact with the other children. She has shown excessive stubbornness for about two months, refusing to move when told to do so, to take her meals, retire to bed, etc. It is apparent that this condition is caused by some nervous disorder, as she does not sleep well at night, something most unusual for a child of her age.

This condition has gradually become worse, until today, when she showed signs of definite insanity, by tearing her clothing, the bed covering, etc.

Will you kindly advise me, as to the wishes of the Department regarding her.

Thanking you, I am,

Yours sincerely,

Élise Lafontaine
Memorandum:

DOCTOR MOORE

Re: Rita Maracle

I should appreciate your considering the attached letter which I have just received from the Principal of the Girls' School at Spanish, Ont., regarding the above-mentioned pupil.

The information on our files indicates that this girl was born in the year 1927. She was an illegitimate child of Percilla Maracle of the Tyendinaga Reserve and was adopted by Freeman Maracle and his wife. Freeman Maracle is also a member of the Tyendinaga Band. His wife died in the spring of 1932 and he deserted the child in August of that year. At that time she was placed in St. Mary's of the Lake Orphanage, Kingston, Ont., as the Indian Agent stated that she was a Catholic.

She remained there until July of 1940 at which time she was transferred to the Spanish Residential School.

April 21, 1948.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Last Fall when the Dr. W.L. Falconer visited here, we spoke to him of the girls needing glasses and he told us the Department would pay the eye test and the glasses provided the prescriptions be sent to Ottawa as there they can be had cheaper than here.

As time passed and nothing was done, early this Spring I asked the parents to pay the children's fare to the Soo where they could have their eyes tested. About the same time Dr. Harvie sent word that an optician would be sent here.

As he has not come yet and I had the advantage of sending some girls with a teacher who went on business, I sent Violet Cooper 01033 Nancy Manetowabe 01081 Mary Ann Oshkahoose 0960 Angeline Enosse 01148

Dr. Stevenson was to send his bill and the prescriptions to the Department.

Two other girls have received money from home and will probably go to the Soo some day. There are others who will not receive anything from home; they will wait for the optician who will come I hope before the end of June.

Trusting this will meet your approval,

I remain,

Your humble servant,

Clotilde Laferrière

April 27, 1942.

Dear Madam:

Re: Eye glasses for school girls.

Mr. Phelan has forwarded your letter to me about the above mentioned subject.

I considered that by now all the girls had been checked and glasses supplied. However, any others that you think need glasses should be checked when the optician arrives and prescriptions forwarded here to be filled. The optician's account should be forwarded to Mr. Laurence in the usual manner and this letter quoted as the authority.

Please bear in mind the question of economy and confine the examinations to the children that obviously need it.

Yours truly,

W. L. Falconer, M.D.,
Assistant Superintendent of Medical Services.

Rev. Sister Clotilde Laferriere,

Dear Sir:

Pupils of this school have need of dental attention. Approximately 57 extractions and 32 fillings are required in the boys' section, and in the girls', 61 extractions and 154 fillings. A clinic of at least four days will be necessary. Doctor Boyd says that three of the girls will have to be put to sleep before extractions can be made.

Yours truly,

J. Howitt

May 11, 1942

Reverend Sir:

It will be in order to arrange with Dr. Boyd to hold a dental clinic, not to exceed four days at the Spanish school. The Department will pay the usual $50 a day, the dentist to supply his own equipment and materials.

It is thought that the regular medical attendant of the school could probably arrange to be present when Doctor Boyd is holding the clinic so that he could give the anaesthetics where patients require them. It is also thought probable that the medical attendant could carry out a number of the extractions that are necessary.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes

Indian Residential School,
Spanish, Ontario,
February 1, 1943.

Dear Doctor Moore,

Doctor Hamill of Blind River has recommended that Charlotte Lazare, No. C983, see a specialist as she has small tumors in each of her nostrils. I understand he suggested Sudbury.

Doctor Hamill is going to operate on the tonsils of two of the children at the Girls' School this week. He will do the operations at Blind River. The two children are No. C1106 Lillian Solomon and No. C1147 Annie Corbiere.

I have received the reports of the X-rays taken by the Travelling Ghost Clinic. They recommended hospitalization of one child, Agnes Solomon, but it apparently is an error as the child is quite alright—Dr. Hamill examined her yesterday evening. I believe Dr. Hamill is writing in regard to this matter. The report recommends that one of the boys be re-x-rayed in six weeks—the diagnosis was probable pneumonia at left base. It is recommended that another boy be re-x-rayed in 3-4 months, and that three of the girls and two of the boys be re-x-rayed in six months. Will you kindly advise your wishes in this regard.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
(Rev.) G.A. Primeau, S.J.
Principal.

P.E. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.,
Acting Superintendent of Medical Services,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.
February 9, 1943

Dear Sir:

A recent report on the clinic held at Spanish Indian Residential School stated that Agnes Solomon had a discharging sinus in her hip and treatment was recommended at Eaton. I wonder if you could check up on this report as the school Principal advises that Doctor Hamill of Blind River, who is the attending physician, has examined the child again and there is, apparently, nothing wrong with her.

Yours very truly,

P. E. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.,
Acting Superintendent of Medical Services

E. M. Shorey, Esq., M.D.,
Clinician,
Division of Tuberculosis Prevention,
Department of Health,
Toronto, Ont.

February 9, 1943

Reverend Sir:

It will be in order to send this child to Sudbury for treatment by a specialist. It would be well to advise either the hospital or Dr. McCullough the date that she will arrive so that there may be no undue delay in having her given the necessary attention.

I am writing to the Ontario Division of Tuberculosis Prevention regarding Agnes Soloman as there seems to be some mistake regarding the report made.

Arrangements should be made to have the other pupils re-x-rayed on the dates suggested. Doctor Hamill might be able to advise you when a travelling clinic will be visiting Blind River.

Yours very truly,

P. E. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.

With reference to Holly Rice, the school term will soon be over and on her return to the Reserve at Caughnawaga we can have her examined by our medical officer there.

Regarding the account we would like further information on several items before approving payment.

Upon whose authority was a nurse hired to attend the dental clinic? It is not the custom of this Department to arrange a contract with a dentist to do certain work and then pay for a nurse's services as well. Medical supplies are sent out from the Department for use in the dispensary. If certain medicines are not available in this stock, the Department will pay for what is required on the prescription of the doctor in charge, a copy of the prescription must be forwarded with the account from the drug store.

There is a total of $9.18 for lenses for Leonard Gross. Was this authorized? Regulations state authority must be obtained from Ottawa. The Department cannot approve of paying for spectacle cases at 50¢ a piece when we obtain and maintain a stock of them here at 6¢ each.

Dear Sir,

It is discouraging enough to be denied a regular medical attendant but when we are refused even the necessary medical supplies, the situation becomes impossible. The Medical Services know full well that we have no regular medical attendant and yet they do not even acknowledge our request of March 19th for necessary medical supplies. Apparently they do not appreciate even the effort we have made to carry on without a regular doctor—or the effort we have made to keep down expenses—a very discouraging attitude, to say the least. Let them try to take care of 126 active boys and see how far they can go without medical supplies. If they are not concerned about first aid and medical care for them, we are. And we are quite concerned that none of the children entrusted to our care die because of their not receiving proper care or care in time. If the Medical Services prefer to pay hospital bills, we are ready to send all sick to the hospital.

The Department authorized glasses for the children last year and finally sent the glasses—without cases. Anyone would know how long glasses would remain unbroken if given to live boys without cases. The Department included a note with the glasses to the effect that cases could not be procured. I took the trouble to search around until I found an optician kind enough to let me have a dozen cases. The Department then refuse to pay for them because they—the Department—"obtain and maintain a stock of them .... at 6¢ each". (Dr. Letter of W.L. Falconer, M.D., File 36-0-13, April 1, 1943.) Somehow it sounds rather contradictory to me.

One of the boys broke his glasses twice and had to have them repaired. The Department—in the same letter mentioned above—ask if this was authorized. Perhaps they will state whether their initial authorization for the child to wear glasses meant for him to wear them only until they were broken, or did the authorization mean that they considered that the child should wear glasses until the eye condition was corrected, if possible. The lad actually had about 10% vision in one eye and 30% in the other.

(over)
In the same letter, the writer states that medical supplies are sent out from the Department for use in the dispensary. Their disregard of our request for supplies needed does not carry out this statement.

The Department authorized a Dental Clinic last Fall. Before the Clinic began, our infirmary was obliged to go to the hospital as a patient—he was 17 days in the hospital—due to a blood infection contracted while treating infected cases among the pupils. The Dental Clinic was during his stay in the hospital. I myself looked after the regular infirmary treatments and the sick during those 17 days—and it saved the doctor more than one call. But I could not remain with the dentist all day long during his clinic which he held during that time. Someone had to assist. I called upon a nurse. I did not call upon the Department to pay for our infirmary's hospital expenses etc., though the infection was due to his devoting himself to the work of the Department. But I did submit a claim for the fee paid to the nurse. It was not allowed. Instead the reply abruptly demanded upon whose authority a nurse was hired! The more one does apparently, the less thanks one receives.

I asked that something be done in regard to one of the pupils at the Girls' School, who appears to be somewhat mental. The writer in the same letter already referred to dismissed the request with a summary reply that the school term would soon be over and on her return to the Reserve at Gaughnawaga she could be examined by your medical officer there. At the time of writing, there still remained three months of the school term. And though the child originally came from Gaughnawaga, I mentioned in my letter that the mother of the child was in a mental institution. The child has no home there now. The father, I am told, is somewhere in the States. Gaughnawaga children never go back to the Reserve for the summer holidays—they remain here until they are discharged by the Department and then return to the Reserve if they have a home and a suitable one. The Medical Services might give our requests credit for having been thought upon a little bit before being made and for taking into consideration various circumstances surrounding and affecting the individual cases.

Our relations with the officers of the Welfare and Training Divisions have always been so cordial and pleasant and an encouragement to cooperation. It is with deepest regret that I write this letter in respect to our relations with the Medical Services. For two months I could not bring myself to discuss their letter of April 1st. But I can no longer hesitate to write as something must be done in regard to our medical situation, and the disregard of our request for supplies that are needed if we are to carry on. I leave the matter in your hands.

Yours very truly,

(Rev.) G.A. Primeau, S.J.,
Principal.

Right Lung

Dear Mr. Irwin:

The church authorities at the Spanish Indian Residential School are making an intelligent effort to commence Boy Scout work at the institution. A Jesuit Father from Regina, now attached to the staff of Loyola College, Montreal, has been at the school for the past two months. He is experienced in the scout movement and has organized the work. Mr. Kisel will be the scout master.

I consider this activity very valuable for the youth of our wards, and the Department intends to assist, as far as possible. Would it be convenient for one of the Ontario field executives to visit the school for the purpose of assisting the local management? The school is located at Spanish, on the mainland, north of Manitoulin Island.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr Ferrier,

Could I have a few minutes of your time in which to give you a sort of résumé of Boy Scout Work in our school up to date, and also to give you a brief outline about plans for the future?

The first nine boys which started in the movement are in good shape as far as the tests in Scout Work are concerned. They have had a good deal of fun and have a good understanding of Boy Scout ideals. The uniforms which you so graciously sent, were indeed a great boost and contributed greatly to create the fine spirit which is now in the troop. The results so far, are far ahead of our fondest hopes.

We are now training our recruits. Most of them are ready for the initial test. There are 29 of them. This will raise the number in the troop to 37 which is 5 more than Scout Headquarters advises. But the boys were so anxious to join that it was very difficult to draw the line at 32 and still be fair to the boys who wanted to join. However there will no doubt be some who will in time, not try to live up to the Scout Law so they will have to drop out, so that in the end the troop will consist of the regulation number of Scouts.

I am enclosing an application for registration for the new boys and also a list of a few things we need. Would you please send these on to the Provincial Headquarters, Boy Scout Association, 330 Bay St.

Toronto.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6219, file 471-17, part 1)
Our work during the winter will be mostly indoor work with a lot of drill on the qualifications for the Second Class Badge. We also expect that the Scouts will stage some kind of demonstration at the Christmas Entertainment in the school. In the spring we hope to work on a project, namely...a Scout Garden. If our plans are successful we shall have about half an acre of good garden land. My fellow teacher who will direct it, is an old and experienced farmer and we are looking forward to an A-1...Garden.

So you see, Mr Ferrier, the boys have made a creditable showing so far and if our plans for the year can be carried out we shall be able to show not only results of character building which are more or less intangible, but material results as well.

Trusting that you will attend to our needs at your earliest convenience.

I am,

Your humble servant,

MEMORANDUM

1. Dr. McGill
2. Schools Branch

Re - Spanish Schools for Boys and Girls (R/C) and Audit.

You will observe from the two audit reports hereunder that in lieu of salaries drawn, the members of the Sisterhood and Brotherhood of the respective Orders have clothing made from the general supply of clothing and material all of which is charged to the clothing expense item of the pupils.

Donations and gifts are also made periodically to various institutions, these are in the form of cheques charged to the grant, and are apparently in lieu of salaries to the staff. From an accounting standpoint and for information of the Department such a procedure is misleading.

No accurate record is obtainable regarding the actual clothing cost of the pupils, and such clothing and donations etc., used in lieu of salaries should be recorded as salaries.

The same applies to dental and medical services for the staff, expenditures of which should be regarded as salaries and not charged to "miscellaneous expense" of the school.

The attached letter is drafted for your approval, and when sent to the Principals, Miss Z. St. James and Rev. P. Mery, it would be appreciated if a copy of your letter be supplied to this office for record purposes.

Representative of the Treasury

Dear Sir:

Spanish Residential School
Roman Catholic
Sault Ste. Marie
Ontario.

I submit herewith a report of an examination of the books and records of the above noted Residential School, covering a period of seventeen months, from April 1st, 1934 to August 31st, 1935.

I arrived at the School at 10.00 a.m., September 7th - Saturday - worked that day until 5.00 p.m., and completed my examination at 8.15 p.m., September 10th.

There are two distinct Schools at this place, one for boys and one for girls.

Although a combined yearly report is submitted to the Department, a separate set of books and records is kept at each school.

I shall, therefore, deal with each school separately.

School for Boys.

This school is conducted by the Jesuit Fathers. The buildings and the land are owned by the Jesuits, Upper Canada Province, Toronto, Ontario.

The Principal, Rev. Father Paul Mery, and the bookkeeper, Brother E. O'Keefe gave me every assistance during my examination, including access to all records and volunteered much information.

Revenue - Cash Book - Cheques - Invoices and Bank, Etc.

The new Cash Book was only supplied last April and has been in use since then.

In addition a columnar type of cash book is being maintained. This book was the one in use prior to April and was adopted years ago by the Order of Jesuits for the convenience of submitting returns to the Provincial House of the Order.

On both sides of this book are columns which are peculiar for recording transactions affecting the religious order only, such as church collections, Mass Offerings, church goods and equipment, retreat expenses, etc.

N.C. Allen, Esq.,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
The Departmental Cash book, recently adopted, records only items of receipts and expenditures affecting the School.

The Bank account is kept at the Royal Bank of Canada, Blind River, some twenty-five miles from Spanish.

A savings bank account is kept in addition to the current account. This account is used to deposit Government Grants, and funds are transferred to current account as needed. The reason for this account is to earn bank interest.

I examined the invoices on hand. Many could not be found. In the past invoices were inclosed with the cheques when payments were made and many of these invoices were not returned receipted. I informed the Principal he should have a voucher to support every payment made and that it was unnecessary to forward invoices with the cheques. If firms insisted upon invoices being returned, they should supply a duplicate copy for that purpose.

All payments are made by cheques with the exception of small cash payments. The cash used for this purpose in the past was derived from sundry receipts. I advised the Principal to provide a petty cash Advance to be balanced and reimbursed monthly. This he is putting into effect immediately.

Receipts and Expenditures - Statement 2.

The per capita Grant is received quarterly in one amount for both Schools. This is prorated according to the number of pupils in attendance at each school. During the period under review $34,145.95 was received and $16,755.14 of this amount was handed over to the girl's school.

The proceeds from Farm and garden produce sold was $247.46 which was derived from the Sale of poultry and eggs.

The item of $2,924.22, being the value of food consumed from the farm and Garden, is in my opinion fairly accurate. An actual record is kept of the produce supplied to the kitchen and the bookkeeper is advised of the value by memo. at the end of each month.

The laundry service is done by the girl's school. The charges are $900.00 per year. Ten months at $80.00, and two months at $50.00.

In turn the boy's school performs certain services for the girl's school, such as shoe repairs, electrical repairs, carpenter work. The boy's school operates the water and lighting plants and the girl's school is charged a share of the cost of operation.

At the end of each month the proper charges are made by bookkeeping entries in cash book, and a cheque is issued for the difference to the school that has the greater charge.

The two schools being distinct, as far as accounting is concerned, I would think that a better method would be for each school...
school to bill each other for the full amount, and cheques issued by each school. In this way the proper charges would be made and could be more easily followed by the Auditor. This matter was discussed with both Principals and they agreed that the present method was confusing even to themselves. They intend to try the method as outlined above.

Salaries.

The members of this Order do not draw salaries. However, in lieu of salaries, certain donations are made to their Provincial House. During the period September 1st, 1934 to August 31st 1935 salaries paid to lay members of the Staff amounted to $1,201.75 and donations amounted to $1,791.44.

Clothing expenses appear exceptionally high being $42.89 per pupil for the year. The rough clothing and boots for the pupils are made at the institution. The working clothes for the brothers are also made and supplied by the school and add to the cost of clothing. A record has not been kept of such issues and the value could not be ascertained. According to the Principal such an expense would be very slight.

Insurance premiums on the buildings and furnishings last year amounted to $692.95. This expense is included in the Buildings and Repairs expense item.

The cost of food is considered quite high. All the bread is purchased. The Principal believes it would cost more to bake than to purchase bread. He considers he is getting his bread very cheaply at 5 cents per loaf, and that the cost of installing suitable ovens and employing a baker would prove rather expensive.

Livestock and Crops.

According to the Principal, the livestock consists of 7 horses, 13 milch cows, 1 bull, 17 young cattle and 500 poultry.

The crop produced in 1934 consisted of 40 tons of hay, 20 tons of corn, 1500 bushels of potatoes, 15 bushels of roots and 345 bushels of oats.

The hay crop last year was only about one third of requirements. Hay had to be purchased to the extent of $400.00. This year the hay crop was very good and there will be no need to purchase any of this commodity.

General.

The new cash book is very much appreciated. I believe in future better and more complete records will be maintained.

The books were in excellent order having been recorded neatly and accurately. The cash book has been balanced monthly and bank reconciliation made. A few suggestions were offered the Principal and the bookkeeper in regards to details and filling of Vouchers which they seemed to appreciate, as they appeared keen and anxious to co-operate in any way possible.
The following statements are submitted herewith:

Bank adjustment.
Receipts and expenditures.
Cost of operation.
Staff occupation and salaries.

Yours faithfully,

E.H. Berthe,
Auditor.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit a report of an examination made of the books and records at the above school on May 14th 1937.

The examination covered a period of nine months, dating from August 1st 1936 to April 30th 1937, and during which I was assisted by Mr. Wey.

Bank Reconciliation

The pass book from the Bank of Montreal, North Vancouver, gave a balance of $803.64 as at April 30th, and there was one outstanding cheque in the amount of $17.50. The petty cash on hand was $44.48, and gave a net balance of $830.62 which agreed with cash book.

All debit entries were compared to pass book deposits and found correct.

All cheques were examined and compared to credit entries in cash book. Cheques were all numbered and attached to the corresponding paid vouchers. The vouchers were examined and with one or two exceptions were correctly allocated in the synoptic.

The petty cash purchases are recorded in a separate journal, are budgeted at the end of the month as to their respective columns in synoptic and cheque drawn to reimburse the cash to seventy-five dollars.

A bank reconciliation is made every month, and the balance carried forward.

Revenue and Expenditures

This statement was prepared from a recapitulation of the monthly synoptic. The total revenue during the nine month period amounted to $5439.50, with the per capita being $4645.00, and $525.00 from Department for the teaching of day students in the school.

The expenditures amounted to $7244.12, and the salaries amount to 39%.

The cost of clothing and food at $17.24 and $41.47 per pupil per year are normal.

L.W. McCutcheon Esq.,
Chief Treasury Officer,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

Indian Affairs. (RC 10, Volume 6210, file 471-24, part 1)
The fuel and light at $241.04 is not large considering the severe winter.

The building and repairs at $369.75 include $194.40 for lumber, $22.23 for repairs to equipment, and $72.00 for painting. The house equipment with a total of $445.08 includes linoleum $154.50, beds $66.00, kitchen utensils $105.61, and furniture $25.09.

The farm and garden with $233.45 includes $63.17 for poultry and $184.60 for feed.

The Miscellaneous has been reduced this year to $204.59, and includes telephone $42.72, Christmas gifts $56.27, publications $22.95, Church supplies $54.32, and postage $12.55.

The school appears to be operated very economically and the cost of operation is curtailed to the Government grant.

The garden provides all the fruit and vegetables required during the summer season, and the 250 poultry produce sufficient eggs during the year for the school's needs.

General - The books and records were found to be in very good condition and all up to date. Sister Alix has charge of all the accounting and could set an example for many of the other Schools to follow in this respect.

I wish to acknowledge the courtesies extended during my audit.

Cash Book, Bank, Invoices and cheques.

The cash book was examined in detail and the invoices and paid cheques were also examined and checked to cash book, all of which were found to correspond correctly. There were no missing vouchers this year, as was the case on my first visit last year.

A bank adjustment statement was prepared, as per Statement No. 1, attached, showing a bank balance of $4,977.11, and a cash balance on hand as $208.43, making a total balance of $5,185.54 at August 31st, 1936.

Receipts:

This statement was prepared from an analysis of the cash book and vouchers.

The total receipts for the year amounted to $21,639.49, of which $17,240.12 was received from the Department covering per capita Grants.

General:

The books and records were found in very good order and neatly kept.

The few suggestions offered last year were well followed and a better record was available this year.

I was afforded every assistance by the Principal and the bookkeeper during the course of my visit at the school.

I submit herewith a report of an audit of the books and records at the above noted Residential School, covering a period of one year from September 1st, 1936 to August 31st, 1937.

Bank, Cash Book, Cheques, Vouchers.

The bookkeeper had been away on vacation for a couple of weeks and he returned only on August 20th. The cash book, therefore, had not been written up for August.

Cash Book, Vouchers, Cheques, Etc.

Bank, Cash Book, Cheques, Vouchers, Etc.

The books and records were found to be neatly and accurately kept.

The school buildings appeared to be in a good state of repair and they present a neat appearance.

The bookkeeping is handled by the same person, Miss Gilbert, and she appears to handle her work very efficiently.

I wish to acknowledge the courtesy and the assistance extended to me by both Misses Laferriere and Gilbert during the course of my visit.

Cash Book, Vouchers, Cheques, Etc.

The paid cheques were available, and these were examined and checked to the cash book. The vouchers were on hand and they were examined by test and the allocations were checked to the cash book.

Receipts and Expenditures - Statement No.2.

This statement was prepared from an analysis of the synoptic cash book after I had completed my examination of the cheques and the vouchers.

Receipts

The total receipts during the twelve months under review amounted to $24,865.56, in which is included the amount of $4,492.56, representing the value of the food raised and consumed at the school. I have prepared statement No.3 on which are detailed the most important items of expenditure.

The Jesuit Order has installed a grist mill and a bakery on their property to supply the bread to the School. The cost of purchase and operation of the mill and bakery was financed by the Order. Both have been in operation since early in June this year. According to the Principal, the bread will be sold to the school at a fair price and will be competitive in price from an outside bakery. The average cost of bread at this school in the past has been in the vicinity of $120.00 per month, and it will be interesting to note the cost next year. Although the bread had been supplied from this source since early in June, no accounts had been rendered to date of visit.

There were no items which could be classed as extraordinary expenditures during the year.

Insurance premiums amounting to $756.06 were paid from School funds as in past years. The buildings are the property of the Jesuit Order, and in the event of a fire, undoubtedly the Jesuit Order would collect the insurance. The matter was discussed with the Principal. He explained to me that they were under agreement with the Department to withdraw $4,000.00 per year from School funds in lieu of salary for the members of the Order employed at the School. This has never been paid in full. During the last twelve months only $3,300.00 was withdrawn on account of salary, and the Principal felt that even by including the cost of insurance premiums the members of the Order were still underpaid. However, it would be better if the salaries were paid in full and the insurance premium paid from funds other than those of the School. The Principal agreed that the manner of financing in this respect was somewhat involved and he promised to consider this point in future.

The net cost of bread for the year, therefore, would be $1,422.78, or an average monthly cost of $118.56. This compares with a monthly cost last year of $120.00. There were no insurance premiums paid from School funds during the year. During the previous year the sum of $756.08 was paid. I submit herewith a report of an audit of the books and records at the above-noted school, covering a period from August 17, 1941 to August 18, 1942.

I commenced my examination on August 19th and completed it the next day.

Bank, Cash Book, Cheques, Vouchers, etc.

The bank accounts are kept with the Royal Bank of Canada, Blind River, some thirty-five miles from the school. Two bank accounts are maintained, one in savings and the other in a current account on which the cheques are drawn. According to the bank pass books, which were written up to August 14th, the combined bank balances amounted to $8,399.40. The outstanding cheques totalled $1,426.95, leaving a net bank balance of $6,972.44. Cash on hand amounted to $422.60; therefore, the actual school balance was $7,395.04, which agreed with the cash book - Statement No.1.

The paid cheques were examined and checked to the cash book. The vouchers supporting the disbursements were examined by test. The postings in the cash book appeared to be properly allocated under the various headings of expenditures.

Receipts and Disbursements - Statement No.2.

This statement was prepared from an analysis of the Synoptic Cash Book and covers a period of one year from August 17, 1941, to August 18, 1942.

Receipts.

The total receipts during the period are shown as $24,603.52, in which is included the value of the food raised and consumed at the school. The amount, viz.: $3,360.63 is shown also as "Contra" under disbursements. The per capita grants received during the period totalled $18,419.11. In addition a special grant of $1,153.00 for 1941 was received.

The cash sales from Farm and Garden brought in $98.35 only.

A record was kept of the produce from the Farm and Garden supplied to the kitchen, and these commodities are summarized.
summarized as follows:

- Milk: 19,731 qts. @ .10 = $1,973.10
- Eggs: 829 doz. @ .30 = $248.70
- Butter: 285 lbs. @ .35 = $100.25
- Meat: valued at = $216.14
- Potatoes: 337 bags @ 1.00 = $337.00
- Vegetables and Berries - valued at = $496.43

Total = $3,350.62

The receipts under "Other Sources" include an item of $1,131.36 received from the Boys' School in payment of laundry services, repairs of clothing, and also for some coal supplied to the school.

The other receipts are itemized on the statement and are self-explanatory.

Disbursements:

The total disbursements during the same period amounted to $24,811.45, in which is included as "Contra" the value of the food produced and consumed at the school.

I have prepared Statement No.3 which shows more in detail the most important items of disbursements under each heading.

A new boiler was installed as replacement at a cost of $1,400.00.

The roof and the eaves had to be repaired at a cost of $350.90.

The other items appear about normal.

From all appearances, this school is operated very economically and with a balance of $7,395.04 at August 18th, 1942, is in a very sound financial condition.

Cost of Operation - Statement No.4.

The cost of operation for the year is based on a net cost of $23,140.66. The average attendance for the year was 126.407 pupils and on that basis the cost per pupil per year would be $185.06, or an increase of $20.25 per pupil over the previous year.

The cost of clothing was reduced from $13.37 per pupil per year to $11.90.

The cost of food per pupil per year is shown as $76.23 as compared with $68.05 for the previous year. Included in the cost is the estimated value of the food produced and consumed and this worked out at $26.58 per pupil.

Staff - Statement No.5.

The staff employed at August 19th is listed on Statement No.5. The information was supplied by the Principal and the annual salaries...
salaries are shown as $5,840.00. The sum of $5,889.40 was actually expended for salaries during the year under review. Provision is made for two teachers not yet engaged at the time of visit. The Principal expected to have the positions filled by September 1st.

Livestock and Crop

According to the Principal, the livestock consists of 2 horses, 6 milch cows, 3 young cattle, 150 hens, 4 hogs and 19 goats, including 6 kids.

There are only about 25 acres of land available for farming and most of the feed has to be bought.

The 1941 crop included 30 bushels of oats, 32 bushels of mangels and 4½ tons of turnips, 337 bags of potatoes and a good crop of vegetables valued at $496.43.

General

The books and records appeared to be recorded up to date and in excellent condition.

The foregoing report, to the best of my knowledge and belief and from the vouchers and records which were placed at my disposal, is a true and complete statement of the condition of the accounts at the time of my audit. As far as I could ascertain there were no outstanding accounts at August 19th, 1942.

I wish to acknowledge the courtesy and the assistance extended to me by both the Principal and the bookkeeper during the course of my audit.

I submit herewith a report of an audit of
the books and records at the above noted school, covering
a period from August 19, 1942 to August 31, 1943.

I commenced my examination during the after-
noon of September 14 and completed it the next day.

Bank and Cash Reconciliation - Statement No.1

According to the bank pass books the bank
balance at August 31, 1943 was $3,027.16. There were six
outstanding cheques totalling $562.65, leaving a net bank
balance of $2,464.51. By adding $400.00 cash on hand the
actual school balance was $3,064.53 at August 31, 1943 -
Statement No.1.

The paid cheques were examined and checked to
the cash book.

The vouchers supporting the disbursements were
examined by test. Several errors were detected in the
allocation of the charges in the synoptic. These were
brought to the attention of the Principal and the adjust-
ments were taken into account when preparing the attached
financial statements.

Receipts and Disbursements - Statement No.2.

This statement was prepared from an analysis
of the synoptic covering the period under review.

Receipts:

The total receipts during the period amounted
to $24,718.15, in which is included, as "contra" the value
of the food produced and consumed at the school.

The per capita grants received during the
period amounted to $15,692.80. In addition a special
grant of $1,153.00 for 1942 was received.

The cash sales from farm and garden brought
$39.05 only.

The school records show the following commodities
having been produced and received in the kitchen:

Milk...
Milk 19,203 qts @ .10 = $1,920.30
Eggs 921 doz @ .30 = 276.30
Butter 519 lbs @ .35 = 111.65
Meat valued at = 137.35
Potatoes 300 bags @ 1.25 = 375.00
Vegetables, berries, etc. = 398.62

$3,213.29 -

The receipts under "Other Sources" include an item of $949.22 received from the Boys' School in payment for laundry services and repairs of clothing.

The school was re-imburged by the Department for repairs and pupils' fares.

The Boys' School sold Delco plant parts for $224.70 and one-half of the sale price was handed over to the Girls' School.

Sundry supplies amounting to $73.91 were sold to lay members of the staff.

Disbursements:

The total disbursements during the same period amounted to $29,048.66, in which is included the amount of $3,213.29 as "contra" the value of the food raised and consumed at the school.

I have prepared Statement No.3 which shows more in detail the most important items of expenditure under each heading.

The school purchased for cash from accumulated school funds approximately 100 acres of land adjoining the school property. The purchase price was $3,500.00, and an additional sum of $30.49 was expended for fees in connection with the searching of title and registrations. The land is registered in the name of St. Joseph's Indian Residential School. The Principal informed me that neither the Department nor the Principal of the Boys' School were consulted prior to the deal being made. There is a fairly good house, which was repaired recently by the school, and a stable on the property. The house is occupied by one of the farm hands. Approximately 35 acres is developed arable land and the remaining portion consists mostly of rough rough land, which there is considerable timber. The Principal explained that, as the original school property consisted of only 25 acres, a very small percentage of the feed needed for the livestock could be produced. With the additional land she feels they will be able to raise much more feed and to maintain a larger herd of cattle.

Cost of Operation - Statement No.4.

The statement shows comparative operating cost for the last two years.

As the purchase price of the farm is of a capital nature, I did not include that expenditure in the operating cost.

It will be noted that there is very little difference in the cost in the last two years. The cost per pupil per year shows an increase of $2.16. There is a slight reduction in the cost of clothing. Food cost shows an increase of $3.04 per pupil.

Staff ...
Staff - Statement No.51

The staff as listed on the statement was provided me by the Principal. The annual salaries of the staff presently employed amount to $6,300.00. The actual disbursement on account of salaries during the year amounted to $6,280.65.

Livestock and Crop:

According to the Principal the livestock consists of 2 horses; 7 milch cows; 4 heifers; 2 hogs; 160 poultry; and 7 goats, including 3 kids.

The crop in 1942 included 75 bushels of oats, 300 bags of potatoes, 4 tons of turnips and 6 bushels of mangles. There was also a good crop of other vegetables valued at $392.69. No hay was produced. The 1943 crop of grain had not been threshed. The potato crop this year was a complete failure due to the very wet season.

General:

The books and records were recorded up to date and in very good condition.

As far as I could ascertain the accounts payable at August 31, 1943, totalled $1,707.46 of which $1,106.89 was paid early in September. An account amounting to $600.57 for coal remained unpaid.

The foregoing report, to the best of my knowledge and belief and from the vouchers and records which were placed at my disposal, is a true and complete statement of the condition of the accounts at the time of my audit.

I wish to acknowledge the courtesy and the assistance extended to me by the Principal and her staff during the course of my audit.

the books and records at the above noted School,
covering a period of thirteen months from August 1,
1942 to August 31, 1943.

I commenced my examination on the morning
of September 13th and completed it the next day.

Bank & Cash Reconciliation - Statement No.1.

According to the bank pass books, which
were written up to August 31st, 1943, the bank balance
at that date was $1,289.59; there were no unrepresented
cheques, but the cash on hand amounted to $125.66. The
actual School balance, therefore, was $2,415.25, which
agreed with the cash book.

I also prepared a bank and cash reconcilia-
tion as at July 31, 1943, to tie in with statement No.2,
which covers a twelve-month period ending July 31, 1943.

Cash Book, Cheques, Vouchers, Etc.

The paid cheques were available and these
were examined and checked to the synoptic cash book.

The paid vouchers were examined by test and
the allocations in the synoptic were checked. Several
errors in the allocation of charges were detected and
they were brought to the attention of the Principal and
the bookkeeper. A number of charges for repairs of equip-
ment, farm implements, and motor car had been allocated
under "Building and Repairs" in the synoptic. I
explained to the Principal that the last mentioned column
was intended to record repairs to buildings and permanent
fixtures of buildings and that other minor repairs should
be recorded under appropriate headings.

Receipts and Disbursements - Statement No.2.

This statement was prepared from an analysis
of the synoptic cash book after the adjustments in the
allocations had been made.

Receipts...
Receipts:

The total receipts during the twelve months covered amounted to $28,405.97, in which is included as "contra" the amount of $6,290.03, representing the estimated value of the food produced and consumed at the school.

The per capita grants received during the year amounted to $18,937.64. In addition a special grant of $1,153.00 for 1942 was received.

The farm and garden cash sales brought $355.23 and are detailed in the statement.

The receipts from other sources as detailed in the statement are self-explanatory.

Disbursements:

The total disbursements during the year amounted to $26,766.24, including the contra amount of $6,290.03.

I have prepared statement No.3, on which are detailed the most important items of expenditure.

The cost of clothing shows an increase of $329.00. The Principal believes that the cost will be reduced considerably in another year as he is in receipt of discarded military clothing which can be used to make clothes for the boys.

The cost of food shows an increase of $440.00 over last year. This is understandable as the prices on most food commodities have risen since last year.

The fuel cost shows a sharp reduction as there was no expenditure on this account during the year, as compared with $976.49 for previous year. Considerable fuel was cut from school property and there were outstanding accounts of $425.00 for fuel at August 31st.

The buildings and repairs cost shows an increase of $420.00 over the previous year. Considerable interior painting was done on the store and stable. The paint cost $199.97. Builder's supplies, including lumber cost $25.15. The Department reimbursed the school an amount of $449.84 for buildings and repairs, including $111.07 for a goat house.

Livestock and Crop:

I submit herewith a report of an audit of the books and records at the above noted school, covering a period from September 1, 1943 to August 31, 1944.

I commenced my examination on the morning of September 4, 1944, and completed it at noon the next day.

Bank and Cash Reconciliation - Statement No.1.

According to the bank pass books the bank balance at August 31, 1944, was $6,441.51 against which unrepresented cheques amounted to $1,728.76, leaving a net bank balance of $2,712.75. Adding thereto cash on hand of $300.00, the actual school balance was $3,012.75 which agreed with the cash book balance - Statement No.1.

The paid cheques were examined and checked to the synoptic cash book.

The vouchers supporting the payments were examined by test. A few errors were detected in the allocation of the charges to the synoptic. These were brought to the attention of the Principal and the bookkeeper and the adjustments were taken into account when preparing the attached financial statements.

Receipts and Disbursements - Statement No.2.

Receipts:

The total receipts during the year amounted to $26,984.69, in which is included as "contra" the sum of $2,748.22 which is the estimated value of the food produced and consumed at the school.

The per capita grants received during the year amounted to $19,578.96. In addition a special grant of $1,153.00 for 1943 was received.

The only cash sales from the farm and garden were for the sale of hides amounting to $10.98.

The ...
The school records show the following commodities having been produced and received in the kitchen:

- **Milk**: 14750 qts. @ .10 = $1,475.00
- **Eggs**: 937 doz. @ .35 = $329.95
- **Butter**: 125 lbs. @ .37 = $46.83
- **Chicken and other meat valued at** = $335.78
- **Potatoes**: 32 bags @ 1.65 = $53.63
- **Other vegetables and berries valued at** = $509.43

Total: $2,748.22

The receipts from "Other Sources" amounted to $1,493.57 in which is included an item for $1,170.76 received from the boys' school in payment for laundry services, repairs of clothing, etc.

**Disbursements:**

The total disbursements during the year amounted to $27,036.47 including the contra amount of $2,748.22, being the value of the food raised and consumed at the school.

I have prepared statement No.3 which shows more in detail the most important items of expenditure under each heading of the synoptic.

Salaries show an increase of $950.60. This is partly due to extra help being used in connection with the farm which was bought last year.

The cost of clothing shows a reduction of $277.02 from last year. Considerable clothing is being made over from discarded military clothing.

The cost of food was reduced by $342.01.

Fuel, light and water show the larger increase in the cost, that of $3,765.01. The cost of fuel at $3,885.63 shows an increase of $2,921.97. The Principal explained that at the beginning of last winter there was very little fuel on hand and that now there is nearly enough fuel on hand to tide them over until spring. There was an account for fuel amounting to $600.57 unpaid at time of visit last year. A delco plant costing $1,599.85 was bought by the boys' school and one half of the cost viz: $799.92 was paid by the girls' school.

The cost of buildings and repairs at $283.80 shows a decrease of $911.14 over the previous year.

House equipment cost at $737.55 shows a decrease of $656.77 over last year.

The cost of Farm and Garden shows an increase of $453.91 over last year when the cost, excluding this purchase of farm, was $1,790.35.

Transport, freight and express cost was about normal.

The cost of extra labour at $454.65 shows a decrease of $746.63 from last year. The extra farm help last year was included under salary this year.

Cost ...
Cost of Operation - Statement No.4.

The statement shows a comparative operating cost for the last two years.

The cost per pupil per year shows an increase of $19.31. The cost for the last year was $1,953.34 higher than the preceding year and there was a drop of 2,599 in the average attendance.

The cost of both the food and the clothing shows a slight reduction.

Staff - Statement No.5.

The staff as listed on statement was provided me by the Principal. The annual salaries of the staff presently employed amount to $7,485.00.

Livestock and Crop.

According to the Principal the livestock consists of 2 horses; 8 milch cows; 2 heifers; 6 pigs; and 150 poultry.

The crop produced last year included 15 tons of hay, 60 bushels of oats, 400 lbs. of mangels, 1 ton of turnips, and 32 bags of potatoes. There was also a crop of other vegetables and berries valued at $509.43.

The books and records were kept up to date and in very good condition.

As far as I could ascertain the accounts payable at date of visit totalled $896.55.

The foregoing report, to the best of my knowledge and belief and from the books and records which were placed at my disposal, is a true and complete statement of the condition of the accounts at the time of my audit.

I wish to acknowledge the courtesy and the assistance extended to me by the Principal and her staff during the course of my audit.

I submit herewith a report of an audit of the books and records at the above-noted School covering a period of twelve months from September 1, 1943, to August 31, 1944.

Bank and Cash Reconciliation - Statement No.1.

According to the bank pass books, which were written up to August 31, 1944, the bank balance at that date was $996.93 with no unpresented cheques. Cash on hand amounted to $337.07, therefore the actual school balance was $1,333.00 which agreed with the cash book balance.

The vouchers supporting the disbursements were examined by test and the allocations in the synoptic were checked. A few errors in the allocation of the charges were detected and they were brought to the attention of the Principal and the bookkeeper. The adjustments were taken into account when preparing the attached financial statements.

Receipts and Disbursements - Statement No.2.

This statement was prepared from an analysis of the Synoptic cash book, covering a period of thirteen months from August 1, 1943, to August 31, 1944.

Receipts:

The total receipts during the period amounted to $28,606.46, in which is included as "Contra" the amount of $5,440.80, representing the estimated value of the food produced and consumed at the school.

The per capita grants received during the period amounted to $19,660.64. In addition a special grant of $1,153.00 for 1943 was received.

The farm and garden cash sales and refunds brought $644.65.

The salaries show an increase of $906.46 over last year.

The cost of clothing shows a decrease of $684.45. According to the Principal the use of discarded military clothing is a great source of assistance in keeping down the cost of clothing.

The cost of food shows an increase of $632.77.
The cost of fuel, light and water shows an increase of $1,615.69. There was no fuel cost the previous year as fuel wood was cut on school property. During last winter fuel wood was cut on Crown land a distance away. The dues paid the Province and the cost of hauling amounted to $666.50. A new delco plant had to be purchased and each school paid one half of the cost which amounted to $1,589.68.

The cost of buildings and repairs shows an increase of almost $600.00. The Principal advised that considerable repairs had to be attended to especially to the foundation of the barn. Reimbursements by the Department amounted to $852.98.

House equipment and expense shows an increase of close to $400.00.

The cost of the Farm and Garden shows a reduction of $517.57.

The transport cost was increased by some $200.00. Considerable repairs had to be done to the school boat.

The cost of extra labour was increased by $613.62.

Cost of Operation - Statement No. 4.

This statement shows a comparative cost for the last two years. The cost per pupil per year shows an increase of $16.59. The expenses were some $2,000.00 higher than the previous year and there was a slight drop in the average attendance.

The cost of clothing per pupil per year at $3.25 is very low. The shoes are made by the shoemaker at the school also a quantity of clothing is made from discarded military clothing.

The food cost shows a reduction of $4.60 per pupil per year.

Staff - Statement No. 5.

The Principal provided me with the list of the staff as shown on the statement. The salaries being paid at present would amount to $8,956.00 per annum as compared with $7,459.20 actually paid for twelve months ended July 31, 1944.

Livestock and Crop.

According to the Principal the livestock consists of 7 horses; 29 milch cows; 24 steers and heifers; 3 bulls; 5 calves; 8 pigs; 25 goats, including 5 kids; and 700 poultry.

The crop raised last year included 200 bushels of oats; 155 tons of hay; 260 bags of potatoes; and other vegetables valued at $472.78. The grain crop of this year had not been threshed and the potato crop had not been taken up. There were 90 tons of hay this year.

There were over 3000 one-half gallon jars of vegetables and
and fruit canned this year and the canning of tomatoes was still being done when I was at the school.

General:

The books and records were found in good order and posted to August 31st, 1944.

As far as I could ascertain there were no accounts payable on hand at time of visit. The monthly accounts for August were just being received.

The foregoing report, to the best of my knowledge and belief and from the vouchers and records which were placed at my disposal, is a true and complete statement of the condition of the accounts at the time of my audit.

I wish to acknowledge the courtesy and the assistance extended to me by the Principal and his staff during the course of my audit.

$2,000.00 due the Community. During the past year an
additional $1,500.00 was borrowed and $2,500.00 was repaid,
leaving $1,000.00 still due the Community.

to the synoptic cash book.

Cost
Cost of Operation - Statement No.4.

This statement shows a comparative cost for the last two years. The cost per pupil per year for the last year at $214.81 shows a reduction of $9.88. Although the net cost was $262.97 higher than the previous year, the average attendance was up 7.21 pupils.

I submit herewith a report of an audit of the books and records at the above noted school covering a period from September 1, 1945 to August 31, 1946.

According to the bank pass books, which were written up to August 31st, the bank balance at that date was $1,017.43. The unrepresented cheques totalled $610.85 less the net balance of $3,506.55 on hand amounted to $3,500.00; therefore, the actual school balance was $3,506.55, which agreed with the cash book balance. In addition there is a victory bond for $50.00. At the beginning of the period there was an unpaid loan of $1,000.00 due the community.
